SPEECH.SPEAKER: BUTTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1,001 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The decision to drastically reduce the ABC Melbourne Showband to half its normal strength is both deplorable and in the worst interests of the listening public. This unique orchestra must not be allowed to disintegrate in consideration of its proven past achievements and present reputation.
We, therefore, call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That allegations have been made by litigants that unjust decisions in relation to ancillary matters are being made at the Family Court of Australia.

We call on the Government to amend Section 79 (1) of the Family Law Act, to allow all Family Courts to be open and publication of details of proceedings permitted, provided names of parties and other identifying information is prohibited from disclosure.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mail Services to Tuggerawong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Tuggerawong, NSW, respectfully showeth:

That the delivery of mail in Tuggerawong is belated and erratic. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Australia Post be prevailed upon to ensure early and regular delivery of mail to Tuggerawong.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant variety rights in other countries has had adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant variety rights in Australia,
and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:
That we protest at the many unwise decisions of our National Government which has resulted in discrimination against Australians in many ways.

That the Government act immediately on the advice of the people as expressed in numerous public opinion polls, and bring to a halt the present huge intake of non-Caucasian people, thereby retaining some portion of the fast diminishing goodwill and public confidence in that Australians have never given the Government any mandate to populate the country with people alien to the Australian way of life.

That the Government give practical effect to the views so earnestly espoused by the recent Minister for Immigration, Mr M. J. R. MacKellar (Hansard, 30.11.72), ex Minister for Immigration, Sir Phillip Lynch (Page 16 Policy book Evolution of a Policy), ex Minister for Immigration, Dr Forbes (Press statement 2.5.72 and Hansard 17.8.72), ex Prime Minister Sir William MacMahon (Press statement 4.5.72), all of which are itemised on attached sheet.
That unwise immigration has introduced into Australia crimes characteristic of certain races, and which through an environmental impact is also influencing the behaviour of some Australians.

That unwise immigration has led to the basing on Australian soil a number of foreign terrorist groups such as the Mafia, Palestine Liberation, etc., all of whom are causing both the police and citizens grave concern.

That the Government dismiss Mr Grassby for his obvious and well known racial bias against Australians as indicated in Parliament by a number of members at the time of his appointment, and also as clearly shown by the attached letter.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should take action to have a national referendum on the subject of immigration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for National Development and Energy tell the Senate on 2 April last year that the Esso company had given a clear undertaking of a multi-billion dollar investment in the Rundle project? Is it a fact that no such undertaking was given?
—I do not recall the date. I will look up the matter and give a response to Senator Button when I have done so.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport: Is it a fact that the Government is considering increases rumoured to range from 300 to 500 per cent in the landing fees and other charges levied upon the general aviation industry by the Department of Transport? Is the Minister aware that rumours of increased charges of such severity have led to consternation in the industry as such action would almost certainly lead to the financial failure of many businesses and organisations already hard hit by previous increases in departmental charges and steep fuel price rises? Is the Minister aware that many of the businesses and organisations threatened in this way provide the only regular and reliable transport links to many isolated communities throughout Australia, especially when roads are closed, sometimes for weeks, following heavy rains and when shortages of essential food items and medicines can be overcome only through the use of aircraft? Will the Minister assure the Senate that before the imposition of such crushing increases in fees is further contemplated he will consult with the official representatives of the general aviation industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Transport, who has provided some information on this matter, that a report on the general aviation industry has been prepared by the Department but has not yet been considered. The report recommends increases in air navigation charges of 25 per cent in real terms, as well as the elimination of some types of remissions of part of these charges available to certain operators. In addition, it is recommended that movement charges ranging from $4 to $20 a movement be introduced at selected major Commonwealth airports. The net effect of these proposals on charges payable would, of course, depend on the use of the major airports made by particular general aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: The report does not recommend any variations to existing rates of fuel excise and airport rents and leases. The report makes an assessment of the likely impact those proposed charges would have on the industry and specifically takes into account the operators' ability to pay those new recommended charging levels. The report does not identify any adverse effects arising from the proposed charging arrangements on the provision of transport links to isolated communities. The Government will, of course, give that particular aspect detailed attention when it is considering the report's recommendations. There has been detailed consultation with the industry on the general aviation study since its initiation in 1978. Since then the matter has been discussed by the Minister with representatives of the industry in what is known as the Aviation Industry Advisory Council. The Minister has made it clear in that forum that the Government has no commitment to any of the recommendations at this stage and has invited the general aviation industry representatives to provide comments on the report so that they may be taken into account when the Government is considering the report's various recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. As a point of courtesy to the Minister I add that I will be putting on the Notice Paper a more detailed question concerning this matter. Can the Minister inform the Parliament whether the Australian Government is aware of the disaster likely to occur in Northern Ireland if House of Commons parliamentarian, Bobby Sands, dies? Can the Minister also inform the Parliament whether his Government has applied any pressure on the Thatcher Government to avoid such a disaster and to save the life of Bobby Sands? If not, why not?
—I will refer the question to the Prime Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DONATIONS TO SPORTING CLUBS: TAX DEDUCTIBILITY

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Treasurer take up with the Treasurer the possibilities of granting tax deductibility for donations to sporting clubs and associations which, in the practical interest of health, have seen fit to reject previous or existing funding from tobacco companies, but which, as a result, need to solicit support from individuals whose normal donations, unlike funding from the tobacco company sponsors, are not currently tax deductible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I was asked whether I would take up the matter with the Treasurer. I will see that the matter is referred to him and seek a response for the Senate.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs seen reports of disturbances which took place at a recent rock concert in the Perth Concert Hall and allegations that some of those who took part in the disturbances-in fact large numbers of them-are members or supporters of the National Front and are recent immigrants from the United Kingdom? Does the Minister know whether there is any truth in these allegations? Is there any scrutiny by immigration officials in Great Britain of those who wish to become immigrants to this country as to whether they are associated with the National Front? Does the Minister not agree that, although in a democratic country one needs to be very careful in applying any sorts of political measurements upon the desirability of immigrants, there are great dangers for Australia if members of an organisation such as the National Front are coming to this country in any significant numbers? Will the Government, if it is established that there are members of the National Front entering this country, make such examinations in future?

—I am afraid that the only question I can answer specifically is the first one, namely, whether I have seen reports of disturbances at a rock concert in the Perth Concert Hall recently. As a reader of Western Australian newspapers, I could hardly have avoided learning about that in recent days. But I was not aware of the suggestion contained in Senator Wheeldon's question, that the disturbances may have been provoked by recent migrants from the United Kingdom who were possibly members of the National Front. As to the detailed question concerning that matter, namely, the screening of migrants in relation to membership of that organisation and so on, I will refer that question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and ask him to provide an early answer.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, concerns the problems of dislocation caused to certain States and to our economy as a result of the airline hostesses dispute. Has the Government given consideration to releasing the two VIP 707 aircraft to fly the domestic routes or, alternatively, has the Government given consideration to allowing some of the international carriers from our near neighbours, such as Air Nauru and Air Niugini, to fly the domestic routes to alleviate the plight of some of our stranded passengers and to assist the economies of such island States as Tasmania?
—I am afraid that I do not have any immediate information for Senator Watson on those matters but I will refer them to the Minister for Transport and obtain a reply.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Government given any consideration to relieving the plight of distant States and Territories such as Tasmania, Western Australia and the Northern Territory?

—I, of course, like Senator Watson, am as concerned as the rest of the population of Australia about the problems of the outlying States. One must be very aware of the difficulties which the people of Tasmania and of outback Western Australia and Queensland are facing at this time. The Government is aware of those concerns and is considering the general policy in the area at present.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, by referring to the contents of a Press statement made by that Minister on 16 April in relation to vitamin and mineral supplements. How does the Minister explain the contradiction between the first part of that statement, in which the Minister for Health goes to great lengths to imply that the status quo will prevail, and its latter stages, and here I refer to the first paragraph on page 2, in which he uses the words, 'dangers associated with excessive intake', et cetera? I challenge the Minister to document the veracity of the statement that latent dangers do exist. Can the Minister provide statistical data to prove this assertion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I became a member of the Senate I practised as a doctor. Occasionally I had to treat people suffering from poisoning due to certain vitamin overdoses. I refer particularly to overdoses of vitamin D and suggest to the honourable senator that there can be no question about the danger of that vitamin, taken inappropriately. Vitamin A can also cause problems. Currently, preparations of vitamin A which contain in excess of 10,000 international units per daily dose and preparations of vitamin D which contain in excess of 25 micrograms per daily dose are listed in schedule 4 of the uniform poisons standard. That means that these high dose preparations are available only on prescription.

ANSWER.PARA: What I must point out is that these restraints on the sale of vitamin A and vitamin D are long standing; they are not new. They were first recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council in November 1974 and were subsequently adopted in State and Territory legislation. These restraints are similar to those employed in other Western countries, including, for example, the United States of America. It was these vitamins and these strengths to which the Minister for Health was referring in the section of the statement which read: 'There were, however, dangers associated with excessive intake of some preparations and some high dose preparations were already available only on a doctor's prescription'. Of course, that is a point on which there could be genuine misunderstanding on the part of people reading the material. The Minister had stated previously, and reiterated: 'It is essential that these safeguards be maintained'.

The toxicity data on vitamins A and D is well documented. For example, I refer Senator Mulvihill to the United States National Research Council publication 'Recommended Daily Allowances' of 1980; the United States Federal Register, Volume 38, No. 142, 2 August 1973, entitled, 'Status of Vitamin A and Vitamin D'; and the United States Federal Register, Volume 44, No. 53, 16 March 1979, entitled, 'Vitamin and Mineral Drug Products for Over-the-Counter Human Use'. In view of this kind of information and the long-standing knowledge about the dangers of particular kinds of vitamin overdose, the problem raised by the honourable senator can be understood and the apparent difficulties overcome. The Minister does not believe that there was any real contradiction in his statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. If one accepts the broad timetable given by the Minister, which seeks in two years time the reaching of some understanding on regulations, are we to assume that it will be possible in the interim for the States to go it alone with punitive or curbing legislation or regulations, or is there an understanding that they will work in tandem with the Federal Minister for Health in the long term discussions?

—From memory, I understand that the Minister for Health emphasised in his Press statement that the intention was that there should be the widest possible discussion following the information which he has released. I take it that the honourable senator would endorse that course of action. The States, as sovereign States, are free to take whatever action they like, but I believe that it is the intention of all health administrations, both State and Federal, to seek co-operative action. Although they are their own masters, I would hope that the kind of co-operative action which has been visible and evident so far could be followed in this case.

—I note that the Attorney-General has said that he has been reading Western Australian newspapers in the last fortnight. I wonder, then, whether he would be aware of remarks made by Mr Justice Barblett of the Family Court of Western Australia, who has recently been using the Family Court to give gratuitous advice to the Government on de facto relationships, which should never concern the Family Court. Will the Attorney-General ask for a report of His Honour's remarks? At the same time, will the Attorney-General also call for a report of remarks supporting the family which were made by Judge Heenan, also of Western Australia, I think within the last fortnight? Will the Attorney-General then tell the Senate which of the foregoing views is the Government's policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read something about statements made by Mr Justice Barblett, the Chairman of Judges of the Family Court of Western Australia. I am not aware of the remarks of Judge Heenan to which Senator Martyr referred. The position is that under the Constitution the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Parliament and the Commonwealth Government does not extend into de facto relationships as it does in relation to marriage relationships. Of course, a great deal of legislation of this Parliament recognises de facto relationships for other purposes, but we are talking at the moment, I take it, about regulating those relationships in family matters such as the custody of children, the maintenance of children, property arrangements and so on. I think that was what the question referred to.

ANSWER.PARA: The position is that the Family Court of Western Australia has not been inhibited by those constitutional restraints. Indeed, one of the justifications of the State Family Court of Western Australia is that it has been invested with powers emanating from both this Parliament and the Western Australian Parliament. Judges of the Family Court of Australia operating under the Family Law Act have found that there are difficulties in situations which arise before them because of their limited jurisdiction, and the Family Law Council, of which Mr Justice Barblett is the Chairman, is examining the whole question of de facto relationships in relation to these problems. I have not actually seen the details of what Mr Justice Barblett said, but I imagine that it related to that type of issue. I will certainly seek to obtain a report of what he said and give it consideration.

The deficiencies I have referred to in relation to the powers of this Parliament in these matters are the subject of discussion with four States. I anticipate that there will be a reference of powers from those States to the Commonwealth Parliament to enable wider jurisdiction to be conferred on the Family Court of Australia, similar to the powers that are able to be exercised by the Family Court of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has either the Minister representing the Prime Minister or the Minister representing the Minister for Defence seen newspaper reports which state that an Australian intelligence secret report said that Soviet Backfire bombers-the Soviet equivalent of the American B52s-were based at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam and have the capability to fly over southern Australia and back with one in-flight refuelling? Did the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, and the Prime Minister confirm the fact that the Backfire bombers were at Cam Ranh Bay without checking first with the Department of Defence? Is it a fact that the Soviet bombers are in fact TU95s, a 4-engined turbo prop aircraft, a fact known by the Chief of Defence Force Staff, Sir Anthony Synott, when he told a parliamentary committee that he did not think that there is any threat of air attack on major cities in the south-east of Australia? Finally, why did Mr Killen and the Prime Minister comment on the incorrect intelligence report when the normal response is not to comment on security matters?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence and to the Prime Minister, if necessary.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INVALID PENSIONS: SOCIAL SECURITY APPEALS TRIBUNAL

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security will recall that I have previously raised the matter of delays in the processing of invalid pension applications and appeals in Queensland. The Minister may also be aware that these delays are being caused because a medical officer has not been appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in Queensland. Is the Minister aware that some appellants in Queensland have been waiting for 12 months for the outcome of their invalid pension appeal? Will the Minister consider an alternative method of hearing appeals pending the appointment of a medical officer to the Tribunal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston has raised a number of matters with me with respect to this matter. I understood his earlier questions related to initial applications for invalid pensions in regard to which I advised him in a prepared answer that there was some delay which was caused by delays within the Department of Health and that work was being undertaken by the Department to remove those delays. There is a quite separate problem relating to those applications which actually have been dealt with and which have not been dealt with to the satisfaction of applicants because, as Senator Colston indicated in his question, there has not been a medical appointment to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in Queensland, and that appointment is necessary before appeals can be dealt with. The number of appeals, incidentally, as I understand it, is not very large. It is a much smaller number than the number of those being delayed at the point of initial application. However, the matter has been receiving close attention from my Department and, indeed, from me.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some difficulties with respect to the remuneration of people on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The level of remuneration currently paid is not as high as that paid with respect to some other tribunals of a similar nature. That is a matter which I have taken up with the Minister for Finance and with the Minister for Administrative Services. I think the matter is at the point at which it has been made an urgent reference to the Remuneration Tribunal. So the matter is getting close attention. I am quite dissatisfied with it. I do not think there is an alternative way in which I can deal with the appeals but I will examine the honourable senator's suggestion and if there is a way of obviating the difficulty I will do so. I indicate here, as I have indicated before, that my instruction to the Department is that no person is to suffer due to these delays. There is usually an alternative form of benefit available-that is, either sickness or unemployment benefit-and every effort is being made to ensure that people are not put in a disadvantaged position because of real administrative problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface my question by pointing to the near tragedy when a small charter aircraft flying between Melbourne and Hobart last night crashed into Frederick Henry Bay on approaching Hobart Airport. This crash nearly cost the lives of six people. The crash was caused by the air hostesses strike.
—What nonsense! How can you say that? What an awful accusation to make.

—I repeat: This crash was caused by the air hostesses strike, because that plane would not have been flying if the domestic planes had been in the air. I hold every hostess responsible for the plane crashing with those six people in it. Had their lives been taken, I believe the striking hostesses would have been held directly responsible for those deaths. Before any further lives are put at risk by this ridiculous strike, I ask: Will the Government permit the Royal Australian Air Force to take over all flights from Tasmania, not only on this occasion but also immediately any strike disrupts any international flight?
—How long have Tasmanian flights been international? You do not know what you are talking about.

—Interstate flights-I thank the honourable senator for correcting me. As far as I can see, the air hostesses are asking for a day off for their wedding anniversary and a day off for their birthday. Good heavens, what is this country coming to?
—How much do they earn?
—Order! The honourable senator will ask her question.
—A senior hostess earns $20,000 a year, plus benefits, a lot more than a senior sister in charge of a ward.
—Order! Senator, please ask your question.
—It is a disgrace.
—Ask the question.
—If I could continue with my question to the Minister-
—How long are you going to take to ask it?

—If the honourable senator ceased interrupting, I could get on with it. I also ask whether the Government will immediately a strike takes place permit international airlines to pick up passengers who wish to travel between Perth and Melbourne.

—It is beyond doubt that the present airline strike is imposing severe hardship on a significant number of people who live in remote areas and who possess only one real mode of transport as do people in the island State of Tasmania. Therefore, the prolongation of the strike is to be condemned, and I believe that every thinking Australian would condemn the strike as such. It is a fearful thing that we have reached an impasse in Australia where one group of people in the community seeks to hold hostage the rest of the community in order to satisfy its demands. Clearly, the recent spontaneous marches, both in New Zealand and in Australia, have indicated that there is a strong public awareness of this kind of hostage system and a strong opposition to it. The Government has under survey various methods by which to try to alleviate the plight of the travelling public stranded in difficult areas. I will refer the substance of Senator Walters's question to the Ministers concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF VICTOR HARBOR RAILWAY STATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I ask: Is the Government, through the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, negotiating with Federal Hotels Ltd for the sale of the Victor Harbor railway station in South Australia to that company? If these negotiations are taking place, is it with the concurrence of the South Australian Government? What are the reasons for the proposed sale?

—It is clear that Senator McLaren has the advantage over most of us in regard to his information sources, and most likely has picked up this matter from the Victor Harbor Times. I have no particular information on the matter, and will need to seek further information from Mr Hunt in connection with it. I will obtain an early reply for Senator McLaren.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of reports that the Queensland Branch of the Federated Moulders Union of Australia has imposed fines on its members who have refused to support that union's participation in the 35-hour week campaign? What action will the Government take to ensure that this intimidation is not permitted to spread to other unionists opposed to this futile campaign?

—It has not been drawn to my attention that any union had taken the action which is mentioned by the honourable senator in his question. I have had experience of such activity in the past. I think the Medibank strike was one in which some postal workers unions took action against their workers. Happily, the workers concerned received legal aid and had the fines set aside. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Industrial Relations. He may well have notice of it and may have some action in hand. I do not know. I will ask him to give a reply direct to the honourable senator. I think most Australians find it distasteful to have this sort of force imposed on people about entry into industrial disputes for which people have no interest. I have no doubt that the Minister will be concerned about the matter which the honourable senator has raised.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. It is being said openly in the community that the Government will soon cease to pay a pension to widows over 50 years of age who no longer have children dependent upon them. Will the Minister advise the Senate whether it is true that the Government intends to cease paying class B widow's pensions in these circumstances?

—I can confirm that there is no intention on the part of the Government to take that action. As with any matter that is raised, one cannot give an undertaking in perpetuity but there is no such proposal before the Government. There is debate in both directions with respect to the payment of social security benefits to women in a variety of circumstances. Many honourable senators would be aware of the fact that there is some agitation for the extension of the class B widow's pension to cover women between the ages of 45 and 50 years. At the same time, bodies such as the Australian Industries Development Association have put forward the suggestion that this is one area in which the Government could consider reductions in the social welfare budget. Whilst it is true that a whole series of things might be considered by a government in that regard, there is no proposal that the widow's pension should be affected.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INFANT MORTALITY RATES IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health advise the Senate of the latest figures on Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal infant mortality in the Northern Territory, including the statistics for 1980? Is it correct that the statistics indicate that between 1965 and 1980 Aboriginal infant deaths have decreased by approximately 400 per cent and non-Aboriginal infant deaths by 500 per cent? If this remarkable improvement as indicated by these figures is correct, does the Minister agree that the dedication and work of Northern Territory health workers in the outback and the Northern Territory health system are beyond reproach and that criticisms directed at them are completely unjustified?
—They are still too high.
—Coming down very well though, Senator.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a Press release from the Northern Territory-I am not sure whether it came from the Minister for Health or from Mr Tuxworth-stating that Aboriginal infant mortality rates do continue to decline and that the latest recorded rates are the lowest ever recorded. I pick up the interjection from Senator Keeffe and reply that I think all honourable senators would agree that the infant mortality rates are still too high and I would want it clearly understood that that is the Government's view as well as the view of every Australian. I think Senator Kilgariff, who asked the question, would be the first to acknowledge that. The improvements are said to be due in part to improved environmental conditions in the Northern Territory. I think that was included in the Press release. In particular, mention was made of improvements in water supply and sewage disposal. I am glad that the Northern Territory can point to some improvement in the provision of these services.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures released this morning by the Northern Territory, I think from its Department of Health, show something like 36 deaths per 1,000 live births compared with 45 in 1979 and a rate of 142 deaths per 1,000 live births in 1971. Those are not the details for the years which the honourable senator requested but I think they give a picture of what has been happening. At the same time, the infant mortality rate in the non-Aboriginal population is somewhere below 10 deaths per 1,000 live births. So there is still a considerable difference. Further improvements in environmental conditions clearly are required if we are to bring that rate down and to continue to bring it down.

I agree with the honourable senator's praise for the dedication and work of health workers in the Northern Territory, including Aboriginal health workers. The only other thing I should say is that one has to look at all these figures with some degree of caution. Over the years we have had debates in this place when it looked as though the rates had gone up. Now we have a situation where the rates have come down. I point out that with a total number of births which might be 400, 500 or 600 in a year, a single death less may affect the rates. We simply have to be a little cautious in placing too much emphasis on a particular result in a particular year. We have to look at the trends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the first of the United States of America B52s will land in Darwin on 5 May? Have the necessary modifications been made to the landing strip in Darwin? What arrangements will be made for the people of Darwin to look over the aircraft if it does stage in at Darwin at that time?

—I do not have specific details. I acknowledge the honourable senator's interest in the arrival of the aircraft. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Defence and see whether I can get the information.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Are there any precedents of which he is aware for persons being arrested and charged pursuant to an ordinance or a regulation or other kind of executive decree which has not received any consideration or had any opportunity for consideration by a legislative body? I will consider the question of what precedents exist, but I would be surprised if there were not ordinances with offence-creating provisions which have to be enforced without this Parliament debating or passing them. Only rarely are ordinances brought to Parliament. The only occasion on which Parliament debates them is when it is sought to disallow them. Certainly some pieces of legislation in the Australian Capital Territory are passed by an Act but, by and large, they are passed by ordinances. TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of legislation relates to the proposed Joint Sitting of the Parliament to deal with matters arising from the untimely and unfortunate premature death of Senator Knight, and is consequential to the Senate (Representation of Territories) Bill which was passed by both Houses of Parliament in 1980. One can only say that it shows how sloppy and inadequate was the original legislation, in that we find the need to bring for the consideration of the Senate, and subsequently of the House of Representatives, a further piece of legislation which will regularise the holding of a Joint Sitting which, I understand, it is proposed will take place in the next week or so.

SPEECH.PARA: The three Acts that need to be amended as a result of this legislation flow purely from the original Bill which was placed before the Parliament and which at that time should have taken into consideration, in the view of the Opposition, the need to amend the other three Acts. The first one, of course, is the Evidence Act. We are now being asked to approve of an amendment to that Act which will enable the Presiding Officer at a Joint Sitting to sign the necessary documents to be presented to the Governor-General. That is a fairly non-controversial matter and one which should have been provided for in the original legislation. One cannot quarrel with this amendment.

This Bill also proposes to amend the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act to provide that the Joint Sitting shall be broadcast in accordance with the established principles by which the proceedings in the House of Representatives are broadcast on Tuesdays and Thursdays and the proceedings of the Senate are broadcast on Wednesdays. The broadcast of the proceedings of the Joint Sitting will take place on whichever day the Executive decides it will be held. It stands to reason that the proceedings should be broadcast on that day, or those days should there be some point of contention which one cannot canvass at this time.

It is necessary also to amend the Parliamentary Papers Act to provide authority for the publication of the proceedings of the Joint Sitting and for protection to be given to the Government Printer in respect of any legal proceedings arising out of the publication of the proceedings of such a Joint Sitting. This view was expressed last year by the Opposition when we were discussing the substantive legislation. The Opposition took the view that a Joint Sitting of the Parliament should not be necessary to deal with a by-election situation or the filling of a Senate vacancy. At that time we did not know that within a year we would be placed in the position in which we are now placed. We took the view that the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly, the body which is responsible to the electors of the Australian Capital Territory, should select a person to fill a Senate vacancy for the Australian Capital Territory in the same way as applies to Senate vacancies for State representation, subject to that overriding change that was agreed to by referendum, that is, that in the event of a resignation or a vacancy occurring on the death of an elected senator, that senator's place should be filled by the nominee of the party to which the late member belonged. The Opposition argued that point in both the House of Representatives and the Senate when the substantive legislation was debated just a year ago.

However, the Government had made a decision that such a matter should be determined by a Joint Sitting of the Parliament. That decision flowed from the experience of the double dissolution that took place in 1974 when for the first time for a considerable number of years it was established that the Parliament had the ability to hold a Joint Sitting-that is, a sitting of both the House of Representatives and the Senate-for the purpose of passing legislation as a result of the deadlock position which caused the double dissolution in that year. The Government took the view that the principle having been established, that should be the process by which Territory vacancies for the Senate would be filled in the event of a death or resignation of a sitting member. The amendments that the Opposition moved on the earlier occasion were not agreed to by the Government. It was decided that the filling of such a vacancy should be decided by a Joint Sitting of the Parliament. Consequently, these three relatively minor amendments to this legislation have become necessary. They are machinery amendments and do not strike at any basic principle. They flow, naturally, from the passage of the original legislation.

The Bill was introduced on the last day of sitting before the Parliament rose for its two-week recess. We are debating it today. It is the intention of the Government to have the matter dealt with in the House of Representatives tomorrow so that the Joint Sitting can take place. The views of the Senate or of the Opposition on these minor amendments matter not; the principle has been established in the legislation that there shall be a Joint Sitting. The Bill tidies up the defects that were in the original legislation and in fact establishes the procedures for the Joint Sitting to take place and to become an effective legal process by which a vacancy shall be filled. Whilst the Opposition has not had the opportunity in the party room to debate this matter at any great length, the Executive of my party met this morning and decided to offer no opposition to the amendments to the three Acts concerning the Joint Sitting of the Parliament. In those circumstances the Opposition will not oppose the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Opposition is supporting this measure. It is necessary that it be passed. The amendments should have been included in previous legislation but the fact is that that did not occur. We need the protection afforded by these amendments for the purpose of the Joint Sitting next week. I hope the Bill will have a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that the debate on the motion that the Bill be now read a second time and on the amendment moved to that motion has concluded. It only remains for me to say a few words in answer to the debate that took place in the Senate several weeks ago. I had anticipated that at least one honourable senator wished to add his views, but apparently that is not the case. The debate on this first important step of the Freedom of Information Bill is now drawing to a close. That debate has taken place not only in this chamber but also in the community and in the Press. —Unless you accept them all.

—Undoubtedly there will be quite a bit of debate about a number of these amendments. Senator Cavanagh has suggested that the way out of that may be to accept them all. I can assure the Senate that the Government is not prepared to accept them all. As I have said in other places, I will give consideration to them. I hope that there will be some room for compromise. When I talk about compromise I do not mean simply that the Government will give in. Some of the honourable senators who move amendments also will have to give in. The essence of a compromise is that each side gives something in order to achieve something. So let it not be thought that when I use the word 'compromise' I mean that the Government will be conceding all. I think I read something to this effect somewhere. That is not what I mean by compromise. As I have said, I hope that there will be a true spirit of compromise in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The important matter that we have to decide at this stage is whether to accept the amendment which has been moved by Senator Evans to the question that the Bill be now read a second time. That amendment has four limbs. The Government could really agree with only the fourth limb of that amendment, which states that the Senate:

reaffirms its continuing commitment to the principle of effective freedom of information legislation, in the belief that such legislation is indispensible to both administrative justice and sound and effective public sector decision-making in the national interest.

Of course, that is really saying that the Bill should be read a second time because it is an important principle. I think it is in many respects a quite unnecessary amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. We would not give the Bill a second reading unless we thought that it indicated a commitment to the principle of freedom of information. The Government cannot accept the other limbs of the amendment moved by Senator Evans. Therefore, in the Government's view, the amendment moved by Senator Evans should be opposed and defeated. The Bill would then be examined in detail in the Committee stage. As I have said, we certainly have plenty of material to consider in the Committee stage.
I shall deal now with the paragraphs of the amendment to which the Government takes exception. The first paragraph reads:
expresses its concern at the failure of the Executive to explain adequately its rejection of most of the arguments . . . of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs;

I put down a very lengthy reply to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs last September. We annexed to that a detailed response to all the recommendations contained in that report. It may be that Senator Evans and some other honourable senators do not agree with or like the response that the Government put down but it is quite wrong to say that there was a failure by the Executive to explain its objections to parts of the Senate Committee's report. Therefore, that limb of the amendment is certainly not acceptable to the Government.
The second limb reads:
regrets the excessive deference--
As it is called-
to bureaucratic influence that appears to have been involved in the rejection of . . . Senate committee recommendations . . .

This Bill is a result of the Government's decision. As is the case with all decisions of the Government, a great deal of discussion has taken place with and a great deal of advice has been received from the Public Service. The Senate has to bear in mind that legislation of this kind has a very great bearing upon the day to day administration of government and the provision of resources. Therefore, every Minister, naturally, has concerns for a Bill of this kind, the impact that it will have on the administration of his or her department and the strain it may place upon the resources of the department. The Senate Committee also had the great advantage in its deliberations of hearing from some of the most senior members of the Public Service about the Bill, which was introduced into this Parliament in 1978 and which was considered by the Committee in great detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very illuminating experience.

—I hope it was an illuminating and learning process for the Committee. Some of the senior members of the Public Service who appeared before that Committee were highly distinguished and experienced public servants. I should have thought that any Senate committee would welcome the opportunity of having the attention of senior members of the Public Service of that calibre.
—As we did.

—As it did. To use the mildest term, I think there is an unfortunate tone to the second limb. Certain senior public servants may have expressed concern about aspects of the Bill, its ramifications and so on. Their views are relied upon by the Government and, I think, the Parliament. Certainly, with the greater development of parliamentary committees, more frequently the Parliament itself will have the advantage of hearing direct the views of public servants of this calibre. We rely very much on the views and experience of these people. Therefore, I think it is most unfortunate, to say the least, that when they provide advice it should be stigmatised as being a bureaucratic influence or something of that sort.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the Government has naturally had to discuss this legislation in great depth and detail with the Public Service. It has been most necessary for us to ascertain the ramifications of legislation of this sort. But the responsibility for government in this country is on the Government itself and indeed, in the end, on this Parliament. Therefore, it is quite contrary to the Westminster system of government about which we have heard a great deal in this debate that public servants should be blamed in any way for giving their views or should be stigmatised as having some sort of baleful influence. Should there be any substance to such charges, the matter is the responsibility of the Government. The fact is that in this case this Bill is the Government's decision. It is my responsibility on behalf of the Government and if any criticisms are to be levelled by members of this chamber or another place, they should be levelled at the Government or at me. Therefore, it is the tone of the suggestions and the insinuations of paragraph (b) which the Government finds, as I said, at the very least unfortunate, if not offensive. We reject that particular limb of the motion. The third limb of the motion reads:

expresses its hope that the Executive will in the course of the Committee stage debate give close and sympathetic consideration to the need for substantial amendment of the Bill if it is to be worthy of its name;

The fact is, as I have indicated already, that the Government will give close consideration to amendments that are proposed. We are doing that already despite the fact that the amendments were presented to me yesterday. I am not criticising that. I can well imagine that they would have taken some time to prepare. I have had them for only a little over 24 hours and certainly I have already given some consideration to them. But the fact is that I am certainly not in a position at this stage to indicate what attitude the Government will be adopting to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to listen to the debate before you can do that.

—I propose to listen to the debate. I have no doubt that I will be listening to the debate for a very long time. What we have principal objection to in paragraph (c) is the suggestion that the Bill needs to be amended substantially if it is to be worthy of its name. The Government completely rejects that suggestion. Even on that point alone the Government would hope that the Senate would reject this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the fundamental issues that we face with this legislation. A point which seems to have been overlooked throughout the public debate on this Bill-when I say public debate I mean what I have read in the Press; I am not referring so much to the debate in this chamber-is the unique feature of this Bill. That feature is that for the first time this Bill gives a right to every member of the public and indeed to those outside Australia to obtain information. It is a right. They do not have to satisfy any particular criteria or any need or purpose for obtaining information. They have a right to information. This Bill gives that right, a right to information in the hands of government which never existed under our law. At the moment, the provision of information in the hands of government is made available, as has always been the case, at the discretion of government, of Ministers or of officials who have authority. Some times, of course, by decision of the Parliament itself information can be obtained but there is no right in law and this is what this Bill achieves. That is a very major difference as far as the rights of the citizen are concerned.

But probably even more important is the new attitude of mind which a Bill of this kind will undoubtedly create in government and government officials. In future, instead of government officials approaching the problem from the point of view of whether the information should be made available and why it should be made available, and so on, the attitude, the approach will have to be: Why should this information not be made available. This really is a very fundamental difference in attitude which I do not say will be created simply by the passage of this legislation but by the experience that will be gained by giving effect to it in the day by day administration of it and in the administration of government. So, there is a very fundamental issue at stake. This legislation is a very fundamental breakthrough.

In the course of the debate in the Senate as in other places there have been criticisms of the provisions of the legislation. As far as I can see, all such criticisms are raised in the 80 amendments that have been indicated already so I do not propose to argue those cases again here in winding up this debate. In my response to the Senate committee last year and in my second reading speech introducing this Bill I dealt with most of those major questions. I would like to conclude this debate on this note. I have referred already to the very new feature of government administration which will be introduced by this Bill when it becomes law. I believe and the Government believes that undoubtedly there will be major problems with the administration of such a major change as this Bill will introduce. Experience needs to be obtained in how to administer it. Experience needs to be obtained regarding what resources will be required to administer it. Experience has to be obtained as to the nature of requests that will be made under it, the ambit of them, the frequency of them and the width of interest in obtaining information under this Bill and so on. It may be that it will all go off very smoothly and the concerns that the Government has will not be justified. Of course we hope that will be the case. On the other hand, we cannot foresee at this stage just what the size of the demands on government will be and what resources will have to be committed to the administration of this legislation. We are introducing it really as the last step in a major package which this Government has been concerned to introduce over a period of more than five years in an effort to improve the rights of the citizen against the government. I instance the establishment of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the office of Commonwealth Ombudsman and the proclamation on 1 October last year of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not be too proud of the last one.

—I am surprised that the honourable senator should interject in those terms because the obligation to provide reasons for decisions represents a major addition to the rights of the citizen in his dealings with the Government.
—That was the original Bill, but what you did to it last year ruined it.

—The fact is that the same considerations had to apply to that measure as have had to apply to the Freedom of Information Bill. There are many areas of government in respect of which exemptions are required, just as is the case in the legislation before us. Again, such measures carry with them resource implications but already, under the legislation which was introduced last year, some 40 applications for judicial remedy have been made. The improvement in regard to judicial remedies, apart altogether from reasons being required for decisions given, represents a major advance in itself. As the figure indicates, the legislation has been most effective. I venture to suggest that in the long run, as far as the rights of the citizen against government are concerned, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, in requiring that reasons be given for decisions made, will prove just as effective as, if not more effective than, the freedom of information legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I was making before I was diverted somewhat was that the Freedom of Information Bill should be considered as part of a total package which has created a major change in the relationship between the citizen and the Government, one that has been for the better as far as the ordinary citizen is concerned. However, it has undoubtedly raised problems for the Administration, especially in regard to the resources that are required to deal with, and give effect to, the new rights. The legislation has been in process of implementation at a time when the resources available to government have been necessarily strained and at a time when the Government has been seeking to restrain the level of public expenditure and activity. Nevertheless, we have been able to achieve improvements in this area. Such improvements cannot be achieved without creating problems, strains and some additional costs. Therefore, I hope that honourable senators, in approaching the Freedom of Information Bill, will bear those matters in mind and not expect to be able to achieve perfection overnight. I hope that they will realise that steps such as these are best taken cautiously and steadily and that progress is much more likely if we proceed in this way rather than when there is a demand that every problem be solved by one piece of legislation.

I repeat that the Government's approach has been to proceed as quickly as possible to get in place a Freedom of Information Act. The Government believes that great benefits are to be obtained from such legislation, that experience will quickly be gained from its administration and that there is no reason to believe that this will be the last attempt by Parliament to provide solutions to problems connected with freedom of information. The Government believes that it would be best advised to wait to see how the measure works in practice and then seek to make further amendments to it. No doubt over the years ahead such amendments would expand the rights of the citizen. When experience has been gained in administering the legislation, we will be in a better position to understand what amendments should be made, rather than making now all of the amendments that might be suggested, thus introducing a measure which, because of the demands that it would create, may well produce further problems and perhaps lead to an unsatisfactory view of freedom of information as a principle. That is the approach that the Government will adopt in the consideration of this Bill.

The Government certainly hopes that there will be evident in the Parliament a desire to achieve a Freedom of Information Act without any great delay. I repeat that it is almost three years since the Bill was first introduced and we still do not have an Act. I believe that that goal will be achieved if a reasonable spirit of compromise is present, particularly in the Senate, during the debate that lies ahead. As I have indicated, the Government believes that the Bill already contains great benefits for the citizen and that the sooner he or she can enjoy them, the better. I trust that Senator Evans's motion will be defeated and the Bill read a second time so that we may proceed as quickly as possible with its detailed consideration.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
