PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that this Bill be debated cognately with the Copyright Amendment Bill 1981 which is the next Bill on the Notice Paper and which is consequent upon it.
—That is agreeable.
—The Minister agrees to that course being followed.

—The Senate is debating the Archives Bill, though not for the first time, and I say at the outset that the Government's handling of the legislation which we are currently debating has been most unsatisfactory. When the Archives Bill was first introduced into this place two years ago there were major criticisms of its inadequacies from all sorts of sources-from the general public, from specialist users such as historians and other scholars, from persons interested in the freedom of information issue and, of course, from members of parliament and senators. Following those criticisms, the Government took quite a constructive course of action in referring the Bill for consideration to two Senate committees, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Each of those committees conducted a thorough investigation into various provisions of the Bill, took public evidence, and evidence from specialist sources, and brought down reports which were constructive and which, to use the words that have just been used by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), had something of the spirit of compromise about them. However, the Government, having the experience and the work of those committees presented to it, has decided not to accept the major recommendations of either of those committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I proceed to a more detailed discussion of the Archives Bill and the improvements the Opposition wishes to see made in the legislation, I would like to raise again some fundamental questions about the legislation. Why do we want archives legislation? What is the national Archives? How should it be set up? How should it be administrated? I think it is pertinent to consider at this stage those sorts of basic questions. What is the purpose of the legislation before us? Who owns the archival material? Of course, the archival material is owned fundamentally by the public, but it is owned by the public through the agency of the Federal Government. The material which is to go into the Archives is all Commonwealth records covering all activities of the Commonwealth Government. It is to go into the Archives to be available for the public, for the Public Service, and for any other specialist users, after a period of 30 years.

I think it is very important to remind ourselves when we get into the more detailed discussion about the faults and inadequacies in the legislation before us that we are in fact dealing with material which is 30 years old. For that reason, of course, many of the timid exclusions and exemptions the Government has seen fit to try to impose on access to this material are particularly unjustified. They might have some justification if we were dealing with contemporary material. When we are dealing with material that is 30 years old, the timidity of the Government is totally unjustified. There are other questions we should ask. Who should have access to archival material and on what terms and conditions? We need to ask ourselves what is the best system of setting up and administering a Commonwealth archives to ensure what I consider to be the two main functions of the Archives, namely, that Commonwealth material is conserved, and that there is proper public access to that material. We should also ask what the relevance of this legislation is to the Government's commitment to provide freedom of information in this country.

When we consider the legislation before us in terms of those basic questions, we can see how basically unsatisfactory it is. There will be no proper public access to a great deal of material. There will be exemption of a great deal of material which ought to find its way into the Archives, and of course there will be total secrecy about some aspects of Commonwealth records which will be excluded from the Archives but about which exclusion the public and even the Parliament will know nothing. I will deal with those matters in some detail.

The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, after considering the Archives legislation in the form in which it was first presented to the Parliament, made five major recommendations. The first two recommendations concerned the composition and the responsibilities of the Advisory Council of the Archives. Those first two have been adopted by the Government, so I do not wish to make any more comment on them at this stage. But the secondary recommendations of the Senate Committee were of much greater significance in terms of the fundamental question about why we have an archives anyway, and they have been rejected by the Government. Because of the Government's refusal to accept recommendations from the bipartisan Senate Committee, at a later stage of the debate I will move on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to the motion for the second reading which will express the Senate's concern at the failure of the Executive to ensure that the Bill accords with all the recommendations of the reports on the Archives Bill 1978 by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I foreshadow at this stage the intention of the Opposition in the Committee stage of the debate to move amendments which will have the effect of including those recommendations in the legislation.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the recommendations which have been rejected by the Government at this stage and which we hope to have included in the legislation in the Committee stage of the debate. In discussing those recommendations I will be referring to the report of the Senate Standing Committee, in particular to pages 18 to 22, because the arguments put forward there are still the arguments that I hold and they are still arguments which have not been satisfactorily rejected by the Government. The first matter of concern was the provision to allow the exemption of Cabinet and Executive Council records from the Archives. In the report of the Senate Standing Committee it is stated:
. . . in the case of Cabinet and Executive Council records no official explanation has been given for their exclusion from the provisions of Division 2.

Of course, the Attorney-General, when commenting on the Senate Committee's report, made a response with regard to our objections to the exemption of Cabinet and Executive Council records. The Minister, on 11 September 1980, made a response but we regarded his response as unsatisfactory. I repeat here the view of the Senate Committee:

It seems difficult to escape the conclusion that Cabinet and Executive Council records are, after all, records of the executive arm of government, very much akin to records of Commonwealth departments and therefore should be treated like any other Commonwealth records under the provisions of the Bill.

We conclude that while the exclusion of vice-regal, parliamentary and court records is acceptable on the grounds of preserving the traditional independence of these arms of government from the executive, we could find no good reason why this same exemption should apply to records of the Cabinet and Executive Council.

We therefore recommended that the Bill be amended so as to remove the exemption provisions relating to the records of the Cabinet and Executive Council. This is a very timely objection for those honourable senators or members of the public who were able just today to hear the complaints of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Andrew Peacock, in another place. Many of the reasons he gave for his resignation from the Government and for his total dissaffection with the leadership of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, focused on the role of the Executive and of the Cabinet. The Cabinet and the Executive Council are part of the Government. They are not separate from it and their deeds and actions ought not to be excluded from any public consideration of the performance of the Government. That was the tenor of many of the remarks of Andrew Peacock, and I think he has made a very important criticism of the conduct of this Government. I make a similar criticism here of the Government's refusal to include Cabinet and Executive Council records within the normal provisions of the Archives legislation. There is no justification in my view, in the view of the Opposition, and indeed in the view of all the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, for the exemption of these records from the Archives. I stress again that we are dealing not with contemporary material, with which there may be problems with regard to international relations, security and so on, but with material which is 30 years old. Why should this material, which after all belongs to the people of Australia, be excluded from the provisions of the Archives legislation? The Attorney-General has given no satisfactory explanation to date. I hope that in the absence of a satisfactory explanation he will be prepared to accept our proposed amendment that the exemption of Cabinet and Executive Council records be deleted from the provisions of the Archives legislation.

The second major objection of the Senate Standing Committee and of the Opposition concerns the exemption of material from transfer to the Archives at the discretion of a Minister. Again, I should like to draw the attention of the Senate to the reasons given by the Senate Standing Committee for its objection to that provision. In paragraph 5.18 and the following paragraphs of our report we stated:
It has been alleged by some critics of the Bill that certain elements of clause 28--
I point out that that is now clause 30 of the Bill currently under consideration-
provide too much latitude for institutions to frustrate the work of the Archives.
Clause 26 of the Bill provides that all Commonwealth records shall be transferred to the Archives when they are no longer required and, in any case, when they are 25 years old.
Clause 27--
Now Clause 29-
provides for the staff of the Archives to have reasonable access to records in the custody of Commonwealth institutions in order to survey and document records and arrange for their disposal.
The effect of clause 28--
Now clause 30-
is that certain records can be exempted from the provisions of these clauses.
Sub-clause 28 (1)--
Now sub-clause 30 (1)-

enables a Commonwealth institution, with the consent of the Archives, to exempt some or all of its records from transfer to the Archives or from access by the Archives' staff. If the Archives refuses to agree with a Commonwealth institution that a record should be exempted from transfer . . . the responsible minister may, under sub-clause 30 (2), exempt a record without the consent of the Archives, provided the Archives is notified of such a ruling.
In particular, paragraph 28 (2) (a)--
Now paragraph 30 (2) (a)-
allows the responsible minister to determine that a record is not required to be transferred to the Archives under the requirement of clause 26.
The Senate Committee further stated:
We believe that the powers conferred on the responsible minister under paragraph 28 (2) (a)--
Now paragraph 30 (2) (a)-

of the Bill are unnecessary and tend to frustrate the basic purpose of the legislation. The sole purpose of setting up the Archives is for the impartial management, safe custody and preservation of the archival resources of the Commonwealth.
I repeat that principle:
The sole purpose of setting up the Archives is for the impartial management, safe custody and preservation of the archival resources of the Commonwealth.

The decision by the Government to allow a Minister, at his own discretion, to refuse to allow material to be transferred to the Archives is, I believe, a fundamental contradiction of the basic purpose which has been set out. Again, the decision was not justified in any way by the Attorney-General when he responded to the Committee's report. So the Opposition will persist with its view that the provision which gives the Minister power to refuse to transfer material from his Department to the Archives, even when that decision has been opposed by the Archives, ought to be deleted.

Our third major objection to the legislation concerned the exemption for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. What has happened since the Senate Committee reported is that the total exclusion and exemption made available for ASIO has now been extended to the other security organisations. We now find that clause 30 (8) of the Bill states:

The concurrence of the Director-General is not required for the making of a determination under sub-section (1) by, or by a person having authority to act on behalf of, any of the following Commonwealth institutions, namely:
(a) the Australian Security Intelligence Organization;
(b) The Australian Secret Intelligence Service;
(c) the Defence Signals Directorate;
(d) the Joint Intelligence Organization; and
(e) the Office of National Assessments.

In fact the Bill is even more restrictive in its present form than it was in the form in which it was considered by the Senate Committee. Contrary to our recommendations that there should be some amelioration of this total exemption of ASIO records from any obligations to be moved into Archives, we now have that exemption included to cover all our intelligence organisations. Our view is that the sub-clause exempting all the intelligence organisations should be redrafted to ensure that the Director-General of each of these organisations cannot make a determination under clause 30 (8) without the approval of the Minister. This, of course, is a crucial issue as far as the Opposition is concerned. We do not believe that security organisations ought to behave unilaterally with no accountability at all to the elected parliament.

We believe that proposition in all circumstances and we most certainly believe it when we are dealing with records which are 30 years old. Of course, the consequence of the legislation in its present form-this absolute exemption of all the documents of the intelligence organisations-is that no one will ever know what those organisations have been doing. No one will ever know about any improprieties committed by any of their staff members nor about any inaccurate but damaging records which have been held and used against members of the public, the Public Service and the defence forces.

We know from the information made available to us in the Hope report that there has been a good deal of bungling by intelligence forces in this country. We know that there will continue to be bungling. We know that there has been impropriety. We know that powers in regard to phone tapping and so forth will be improperly used from time to time. In fact, in the view of some of us, they are always improperly used. We know that, because of the calibre of people who go into some of these services, there will be an abuse of the secrecy and of the power. We know that damaging records are kept on Australian citizens, including members of parliament, and yet all of this bungling and impropriety will be a secret for ever. Those organisations will never be made accountable in any sense, so the mistakes they are making now will still be a secret in 30 years from now and will be a secret for ever. That is totally unacceptable to the Opposition. I would be very surprised if it is acceptable to many Government senators.

The Opposition will move accordingly in the Committee stage to implement the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee in those three major areas. But there are some other matters which I wish to raise in regard to the Government's performance in setting up archives legislation and a national archives institution. My criticism of the Government in respect of this matter goes beyond the inadequacies of the legislation before us. Not only does the legislation provide for unnecessary, undemocratic and unjustified exclusions and exemptions, and not only does it reinforce the Fraser Government's policy that ASIO and other secret organisations must be responsible to no one but their own directors-general and accountable to no one in their allocation of resources, but also the Government, in its general approach to resource allocations to the Archives, has adopted a penny pinching approach which ensures that the Archives will not and cannot function properly.

I am gratified that while I am making these remarks the Director-General of the Archives, Professor Neale, is with us and is listening to my remarks because for some years now I have been using the opportunity presented to me by the Senate Estimates committee meetings to pursue with Professor Neale the question of staff and funding for the Archives. Every time I have raised this question I have received a similar disappointing answer. Only last night the matter was raised again. Professor Neale again had to confirm the fact that the Archives staff allocation, the level of trained staff available to the Archives and the facilities for the Archives are totally inadequate for the task which the Government has given it. This is not just a matter of budgetary priorities or of budgetary constraints. I attribute a more sinister motive to the Government in this matter.

The Government knows that in order for the Archives to function properly, even after the present legislation, it will require a great deal of trained staff, a great deal of senior staff-people who are able to make the very sensitive and important decisions that need to be made about the preservation and destruction of material and so on. The Government knows that archival material will not last for ever if it is not properly housed and conserved; it will rot away. The upshot of the present situation is that an enormous amount of archival material which belongs to the Australian public and which ought to be available to scholars, members of the public, journalists and other people to peruse is rotting away. The situation in respect of much of the material is by now, I imagine, irrecoverable. With regard to other very large amounts of material, it will soon be irrecoverable if the Archives, as an institution, is not given adequate staff and resources. One of the problems is not only a general shortage of staff but also a shortage of appropriately trained staff. The Government has made very little attempt to assure appropriate training for archival staff. It has deliberately reduced the staff available to the Archives at a time when the demand on its resources is rapidly increasing.

I will take the liberty to repeat a point made to a Senate Estimates committee last night by Professor Neale, that whatever the Government does with the public sector, whatever cuts it makes in the activities of the public sector, however it reduces the functions of the Public Service and the numbers of public servants employed, the work of the Archives will continue to grow. The material is there and there will now be a statutory responsibility for material to be passed into the Archives. So whatever happens, if the Public Service were to be cut in half tomorrow, the work of the Archives will not be reduced in any way. The work of the Archives will grow. At a time of this rapidly increasing demand on the resources of the Archives, the Government has actually reduced the staffing level available. So we have a situation where an undefined amount of archival material is rotting away and will continue to rot away and thus be unavailable to the people of Australia.

I want to make a couple of points with regard to the copyright legislation which we are debating cognately with the Archives Bill, and which is subsequent upon the Archives Bill. The Opposition does not wish to amend the Copyright Amendment Bill, which simply has the purpose of providing for the Archives to be the repository of certain material under the Archives Act. The Bill will enable broadcasting and television organisations to deposit with the Australian Archives so-called ephemeral recordings which the Director-General of the Australian Archives certifies as being of exceptional documentary character. This material may include videotape, cinematographic film or sound recording. So far, so good. But I would simply make this point. I have received a number of what seems to me to be very well founded representations expressing concern that there is in Australia no effectively functioning national film archives at this stage. The National Library performs some national film archive functions. The national Archives fulfils others. But at present a great deal of our national film history is being lost through neglect, poor storage facilities and inadequate administration. At this point in the debate I do not want to raise the issue as to whether there should be a separate national film archives, although of course many people interested in preserving Australian film are now lobbying for such an institution. I would simply urge the Government to investigate immediately the matter of ensuring the safety and permanent conservation of film, video and sound material of national historical and social interest. I do not believe that the Copyright Amendment Bill currently before us is wide-ranging enough to do that.

It is clear from my remarks that the Opposition has a number of very serious reservations about the Bill before us, and we will wish to move amendments in the Committee stage of the debate. I should point out that my colleague, Senator Tate, who is a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, will follow me in this debate and will describe in some detail the response of the Opposition to the Government's refusal to accept most of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs concerning the Archives Bill. At this point of the debate I wish to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. On behalf of the Opposition I move:
At end of motion, add:

', but the Senate expresses its concern at the failure of the Executive to ensure that the Bill accords with all the recommendations of the reports on the Archives Bill 1978 by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading of the Archives Bill 1981 and the Copyright Amendment Bill 1981 and to make some general remarks about the Bills before us. The Archives Bill has, in the last few years, to a certain extent been somewhat overshadowed by the debate and controversy about the Freedom of Information Bill. I will speak mainly in connection with its association with freedom of information, recognising that the major part of the consideration for it was given to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which has of course reported on the Archives Bill. In 1978 the Bill was also referred to my Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, for inquiry and report as soon as possible. We looked at the Bill as it related to issues common to or related to the inquiry into the Freedom of Information Bill 1978. Consequently, my remarks will relate primarily to that aspect of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Opposition's attitude to the Bill is a critical one, and as a member of the Senate Committee which unanimously reported in connection with the Bill I, too, am critical of provisions in the Bill and regret the failure of the Government to this stage to have accepted the substantial parts of my Senate Committee's report. I do not propose to vote for the Opposition amendment. Although I think it expresses the concern which I certainly share in relation to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I do not think it adds very much to the situation. We will, after the second reading of this Bill, pass to the Committee stage. I hope that in the course of the consideration amendments will be moved which will substantially improve in particular the Archives Bill.

I think it is important to realise that the Archives Bill achieves an important purpose, that is, it sets in legislative framework the development of the National Archives. It creates a department which of course has already, in a de facto way, been operating for some time. The Bill will set out legislatively the way in which the department is to operate. I think it will provide much greater protection for the records of this community. These records need to be collected and proper provision needs to be made for their preservation. The records need to be collated properly and there needs to be provisions for proper access to them by members of the public, by historians and by the many people who are concerned not only with keeping the history of government and the history of this country, but also of expanding knowledge of it and doing research, and proceeding from research to useful publication.

It is worth remembering that this whole development springs largely from a report given by an overseas expert, Dr W. Kaye Lamb. His report of September 1973 was made to the Parliament of this country. It set out a framework which very basically is now followed by the legislation for the Archives organisation. It is perhaps worth repeating what was said by Dr Lamb at page 5 of his report. Under the heading 'Functions of the Archives' Dr Lamb says:
These may be summarised in a single sentence:

To watch over the care, handling and disposition of the records of the Government from the time they are created until they are destroyed or selected for permanent preservation, and to provide or arrange for access to records that can be made available to members of the public for research.

He proceeds therefore in that report to suggest provisions which are now to be found substantially in this legislation. The important decision that was made in the Bill, namely, to have the continued period of open access after 30 years, is one which was certainly canvassed before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. In fact I think the time is too long. There is no fixed period of open access from one country to another. The period varies in different countries.

The evidence which was given to the Senate Committee did not indicate any particular desire or strong support for a reduction of that period and the Committee did not recommend a change. It is important, in the period before the expiry of that time limit, for proper arrangements to be made and that we have an adequate organisation to collect government records. I do not mean that archives should retain all the records that may be in existence, many of which probably have no historical significance and would only clutter storage facilities and cost the taxpayers a great deal. On the other hand, it is terribly important that if there is to be any erring, it should be on the side of preservation and not on the side of destruction of records. Therefore, there must be in the legislation proper arrangements to ensure that incorrect decisions are not made, decisions which in respect of records of this nature cannot be corrected because the records will be gone. We know that, in this country, all too few records have been preserved, that we have not always had a proper historic sense, that a great deal of our early records which, after all, are only about 150 years old have gone and that we have not, until recent years, developed a proper appreciation of their value.

I now turn to the actual provisions in this legislation relating to access, which provisions are in a number of respects inadequate. The examples which I will give have arisen in many ways. One finds that, so far as the records are concerned, the problems which we face in respect of the freedom of information legislation are faced also in this area. Logically, a common policy and common provisions ought to apply in one area just as in another area. In fact, the case for limiting access to older records is even weaker than is the case in respect of freedom of information to current or reasonably recent documents. The level of danger does not attach to documents which are older than 30 years if they are made available. The arguments against the release of documents in the areas of national defence, international relations and so forth, become weaker and weaker as time goes on. Yet one finds from the inquiries which I have made and from the people who have written to me that a very timid attitude still prevails in this community in respect of records. I have here a copy of a record which relates to the Coinage Act and which goes back to the year 1920. The documents are from the Prime Minister of the day and are in relation to the British Government's decision on coinage. These documents are still not available to the community. I do not say that they are necessarily of any great importance. I would not think that they are now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Mount Kosciusko centenary documents.

—Yes, I will come to that. These documents are now 60 years old. As I understand it, we are still waiting on the Cabinet to release them. I think the Cabinet has been asked to release these 60 years old documents, but they have not been released to the public. I think we should be concerned not only that this legislation should not over-emphasise the restrictions but also that there should be not too timid an observance and use of the powers to retain documents in that sort of situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed also that parliamentary records-records which the Australian Archives has-are denied to researchers because the Archives has to have the permission of the Speaker of the House of Representatives or the President of the Senate before they are made available. These records are quite ancient and do not appear to be ones which would hurt anybody if they were made available to researchers. The Archives officers are not even able to disclose the existence of some of these records. I would like to read from a minute paper of last year from the Australian Archives which refers to an occasion on which a departmental staff member wanted to release knowledge of the existence of the records but was told that the Archives office was the unofficial custodian but the condition of transfer was that we must not reveal their existence to researchers. The person further said: 'I, as reference officer, could not inspect what is held in order to advise the researcher whether the material she requires does exist'. Without going into great detail about that, it would appear to me that it is a very extraordinary situation in this country when the existence of ancient records cannot be revealed and the people who are searching for them cannot even get to first base.

Recently Senator Puplick and I went to the Australian Archives to see the very interesting new building and the operations there. The Archives is in the course of moving to new premises. I think it ought to be an effective operation and I believe that in general it is. While we were there we were shown some files. One of those files related to the 1934 Victorian centenary celebrations and the relations between the Commonwealth Government and Victorian Government in connection with those celebrations-that is, 46 years ago when those celebrations took place. We saw in this file a number of documents which are bagged, I think the expression is-they are covered so that they cannot be read. That is, these documents are not to be released; they were hidden. Because Cabinet has not so far given permission to release these records, records in relation to co-operation between the Commonwealth Government and Victorian Government in regard to the Victorian centenary celebrations in 1934 are still not available to members of the public but are elaborately bagged and kept hidden. I cite these sorts of examples to illustrate that, whatever is done about this legislation, we must be sure that there is not excessive power not to disclose the existence of records. One needs to go further and say that one hopes that, in the actual operation of the provisions of this legislation, there will be a greater willingness to make available documents in these areas.

When the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs considered the matter it was concerned with the fact that the provisions in the legislation provided for a number of organisations and bodies to be exempt from the terms of the legislation. When the Committee considered this matter it examined, and had evidence before it about, the nature of these exemptions. The Committee in paragraph 33.24 of its report stated:

Very strong objection was expressed by archivists, historians and others to the exclusion of Cabinet records from the access provisions. No one, it seems, was content with the assurance that these records would probably be made available for public access in the same fashion as other records. We clearly detected a residual fear among critics that these records would in fact be exempt from public access, and in any case it was felt that these records are so central to any examination of Australian history that their availability should be assured.

The Committee went on to refer to this view which was held by witnesses in respect of Cabinet records. I think they are very important documents on the history of this country. If after 30 years there is a retention of Cabinet records-other matters could be put in the same category-I am afraid we will find a great deal of restriction on the ability of historians to find out what has happened in this country and to record it well. As a result of this, the Committee made recommendation 33.29 of its report, which states:
Part V, Division 1 of the Archives Bill should be amended so that no category of records is excluded from the open access provisions of the Bill.

I believe it is important that that recommendation should be implemented and we should be very careful to make the necessary amendments accordingly. In addition, one finds that the grounds of exemption from access in the Bill are very extensive. I fail to see the purpose of some of them as they relate to documents that are more than 30 years old. Clause 33 of the Bill contains a number of exemptions which mirror very much the exemptions proposed by the Government in the Freedom of Information Bill. For example, clause 33 refers to:

information or matter the disclosure of which under this Division . . . could reasonably be expected to, have a substantial adverse effect on the interests of the Commonwealth or of a Commonwealth institution in or in relation to pending or likely legal proceedings;

This is 30 years after the document came into existence. One fails to see the likelihood of legal proceedings breaking out after that period. The same applies to information on the conduct of an investigation of an offence. The idea that legal offences will be pursued after 30 years seems to me to be highly unlikely. Of course, the same exemptions arise in regard to matters of defence and foreign affairs. One always has the fear, and we also have it in relation to freedom of information, that these exemptions will be used to restrain public knowledge of these matters. In recommendation 96 of the Committee's report we have recommended that exemptions protecting information obtained from other governments in confidence should be deleted and those protecting Commonwealth-State relations should also be deleted, and similarly in a number of other circumstances set out in that recommendation.

I believe that it will be important in the examination of this Bill in the Committee stage to look very carefully and strongly at the proposed exemptions and reduce them to the lowest possible minimum. Generally, as a government, we have undertaken that we will make available as much material as possible. That statement was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in 1976. He assured people that the desire for freedom of information generally would be met in that way, with as much information as possible being made available. I think that in this area more could be made available.

Apart from the provisions in regard to access, my Committee considered very closely the provisions in this Bill relating to the procedures that will be adopted. Without going into a great deal of detail at this stage, the Committee made a recommendation on the use of the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the increased power for the Ombudsman to facilitate access in this area. It is regrettable that the Government has not accepted that recommendation 104. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) stated:

It is the view of the Government that the Ombudsman's existing powers are sufficient for him to play a substantial role in relation to matters arising under Freedom of Information and Archives legislation. Therefore no change will be made to the Ombudsman's powers other than to make it clear that the Ombudsman is not precluded from investigating a matter which is also subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

In the debate on the Freedom of Information Bill a number of amendments will be moved which I hope will bring about what the Canadians are doing in regard to their Information Commissioner and provide a facility whereby the person who can act quickly and most inexpensively-the Ombudsman in our case; the Information Commissioner in the case of Canada-will have greater power to make practical use of this legislation in both the archives area and the freedom of information area. In addition, the Committee recommended that there should be a 3-year review of this legislation, similar to the review provided in the Freedom of Information Bill. That recommendation, I regret, also has not been accepted. I think it would be unwise for us not to have regular reviews of the operation of this legislation. Likewise, the recommendation for the restriction to 60 days for reply when an application is made under this Act has not been accepted. Generally speaking, in a number of areas I think the procedures are in considerable need of tightening up if this is to be an effective Act.

Finally, I refer to the destruction of records. I have already said that in this area records destroyed have gone forever. It is important that we err not on the side of destruction but on the side of preservation. The Committee considered this matter very closely, and at paragraph 34.28 made this recommendation:

The Archives Bill should be amended to provide that the Australian Archives shall not permit or approve the destruction of a Commonwealth record until the proposal to destroy the record has first been notified to a meeting of the Advisory Council on Australian Archives.

The Advisory Council on Australian Archives is set up under this legislation. It is true that it is not an executive body. However, surely it is a suitable body to be notified of intentions to destroy fresh areas of documentary archival material. If it is given that opportunity and it is advised then there can be protests and complaints. I am sorry that to this stage that recommendation has not been accepted by the Government. I believe that it is important for those people, who serve on the Advisory Council and who have the special knowledge and skills, to be in a position to be advised of proposed destructions.

This is a Bill which will achieve a valuable aim because it is setting up the organisation of the Archives on a proper basis. However, the proper basis must be one that is not only effective but also gives the greatest possible access to material to those who are concerned with it. The legislation is not concerned with the great wide field which freedom of information covers, which has immediacy, a purpose, and a need for people in practical, operating life. I am not suggesting that historians are not practical people, but in the area of archives I think it is important, as a corollary to freedom of information, that we should make this an excellent Bill. I hope we will in the Committee stage of this Bill, increase the opportunities for Australian people to obtain and to use the records of this country. I support the motion for the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I follow a man of the standing, knowledge and integrity of Senator Alan Missen in the debate on the second reading of the Archives Bill. His concern and efforts on behalf of the Australian community to obtain information of both current and archival interest in order to enable our community to function that much better are well known. I really follow as an apprentice to him. However, I say on behalf of the Opposition that we welcome the Bill in principle because it gives a statutory format and a legislative base to the arrangements under which our Australian community can have access to its history insofar as that history is contained and documented in the official records of the administration of the affairs of this nation. It is a matter for commendation of the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, and of the Government that at last we are out of the realm of Cabinet directives made from time to time, perhaps overlapping from time to time, under which I understand the Australian Archives has operated, and are now in the realm of a publicly available statutory framework for the operation of the Archives. In that respect, as I have said, the Bill and the efforts of the Government are certainly to be welcomed. The core of the Bill insofar as I wish to comment on it lies in paragraphs (h) and (j) of clauses 5 (2). The functions of the Australian Archives are stated to be, among other things, to encourage, facilitate, publicise and sponsor the use of archival material, and to make Commonwealth records available for public access in accordance with this legislation, and to take part in arrangements for other access to Commonwealth records. It is the ability of the Archives to achieve those objects that I wish to examine this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the objectives set out there are ones which would commend themselves to everyone in this chamber. It is very important not only that there be a power within the Archives to make available such records for public access but also that the Archives have within its charter an encouragement actually to sponsor and itself encourage the use of those archival materials. In other words, it is to have something of an initiatory or encouraging role, and not merely respond to the requests made by historians and other members of the community for materials. As I have said, those functions are the basic ones upon which the structure of the Bill is of interest to me.
Clause 32 is a very important provision. It reads:

. . . the Archives shall cause all Commonwealth records in the open access period that are in the custody of the Archives or of a Commonwealth institution, other than exempt records, to be made available for public access.

The importance here is that no interest or reason needs to be proffered or put forward by the person seeking access to such documents. There is to be no assessment or judgment by the Archives or any person concerning the claim by an applicant for a record for his or her perusal. In that way a very important right is established. Admittedly, the terms are not the same as those of the Freedom of Information Bill, which speaks of a legally enforceable right, but the cumulative effect of having documents in this public access period, together with certain rights of appeal, is to confer a statutory right, if not in such terms, and is certainly to be welcomed. In that respect the Government and Senator Durack are to be commended for creating this right for the first time within the Australian community. But the question, of course, is: To which documents will this right, which is absolute in its terms, apply? It will apply to those documents in the open access period. One can see from clause 3 (7) that the open access period is defined in such a way that a record falls within it if a period of 30 years has elapsed since the end of the year ending on 31 December in which the record came into existence.

There was some discussion before the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs as to whether a 30-year period was appropriate. It was argued by some, but surprisingly by very few and not by the historians themselves, that a shorter period might be preferable. On the whole, considering a range of matters including the need, as it was put to us, to preserve the anonymity and integrity of public servants who may have given advice which is contained in such documents-not that that argument weighed very heavily in light of the Freedom of Information principles which have been well expounded in this chamber in the recent past-and in light of a series of arguments which are available for perusal in the Senate Committee's report, the Committee accepted that that 30-year period should obtain. It did so in order that documents more than 30 years old should be available as of right to an applicant who wanted access in order to peruse and make use of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not more advanced than the British or American policy, is it?
—As to time or as to--
—Time.

—There was some obscurity in the evidence given but I do not believe that we are in advance of those countries. The point I am making is that the Senate Committee decided not to shorten the period because it may be that as one shortens the period more and more documents will fall into sensitive categories where international relations may be adversely affected or where the commercial value of a particular record may still be current. It was hoped that by keeping the period of 30 years almost every document in the possession of the Archives would be available because the time for the sensitivity of the documentation would have passed. It was really on that basis that the 30-year period was accepted by the Senate Committee. In other words, we wanted the open access period to operate as such. Instead, we find, I regret to say, an array of exclusions and exceptions which is quite vast, perhaps not in the actual shelf kilometres of archival material that might be involved but certainly inasmuch as the exclusions and exemptions go to the very documents which are of primary interest in trying to come to grips with our history as a nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, excluded by this Bill are records of the Governor-General, the Houses of Parliament, Federal courts and Cabinet. It might be worth while pausing for a moment to see what is involved in excluding Cabinet records from the operation of the Act insofar as the Act confers a right to obtain access to these documents which, as I keep on emphasising, are by definition at least 30 years old. One finds, for example, that the definition of what comes within a Cabinet record in clause 19 embraces not only a record that has been submitted to Cabinet for its consideration or is or was proposed by a Minister to be so submitted-in other words, it does not even have to go before the Cabinet-but also an official record of the Cabinet; a copy of, or a part of, a record referred to in either of the preceding categories, or a record the disclosure of which would involve the disclosure of any deliberation or decision of the Cabinet, other than a record by which a decision of the Cabinet was officially published.

One can see from that range of matters that documents which are absolutely essential to the understanding of Australia's history-documents from the Cabinet itself; documents submitted to the Cabinet or even proposed to be submitted to the Cabinet-will not be available as of right in a public access way under the new Bill. This also applies, of course, to Executive Council documents. I recall one of the witnesses saying that it is as though one were trying to come to grips with the history of a company or a corporation without having access to the minutes of the meetings of the board of directors. It is true to say that under clause 21 regulations may be made by the Governor-General allowing access to the documents which I have just outlined. But, as the Senate can see, this takes the matter from the realm of right to the realm of dependence on Cabinet discretion. So access to all the documents which I have mentioned will be available only if-dependent on political criteria, no doubt-the Cabinet decides that they should be made available. It is this movement of those documents from the situation of access as of right to a discretionary dependence on the Cabinet which is of concern and which is not welcomed at all by the Opposition or, indeed, by the Senate Committee. It explains in part the moving of the amendment to the question that the Bill be now read a second time which is before the chamber.
