TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Walsh for ensuring an audience on this most gripping topic of the Archives Bill. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was saying that the presentation of the Bill by the Government is to be commended in that it does provide a statutory basis, a legislative framework, for access by the Australian community to those documents which embody so much of Australia's history insofar as it is contained in documents within the possession of the Commonwealth. I also commended the Government in that the Archives Bill, for the first time, establishes the right of an applicant to such material which is at least 30 years old. In other words, no interest or special reason has to be put forward for assessment by the Archives or any other person in order to obtain a document which is in the open access period.

SPEECH.PARA: But the question then arises: Which documents fall within that period? I pointed out that there is a category of very important documents which are excluded from the open access period. That category includes documents of the Governor-General, of the Houses of Parliament, of the Federal courts, of the Cabinet, of the Executive Council and so on-in other words, documents which are absolutely essential and central to coming to grips with the history of this nation. I pointed out that there is some amelioration of this exclusion but only insofar as a discretion is exercisable by the Government to permit access to such excluded or otherwise excluded records and documents. So what one has in relation to these documents which are at the heart of the public administration of this country is a discretionary power on behalf of the Government-in other words, exercisable by reference to criteria which can only be guessed at-rather than the exercise by an applicant within the Australian community to have the record or document for perusal as of right. While dealing with this Division of the Bill I record a pleasing feature of it, namely, that in relation to documents and records of royal commissions, such documents are to be made available despite a direction by the royal commissioner that public access was not to be given. In that respect one can only say that the Bill is to be commended.

We move from the exclusions contained in the Bill to what are known as the exemptions. The right extends only to those documents in the open access period which are not exempt from the operation of the Bill. There may be a case for some exemptions so long as these are closely defined and subject to safeguards regarding the exercise of the power to declare or identify a record as exempt. But in the Bill we find some 11 categories of such exemptions contained, for the interest of honourable senators, in clause 33. I have to say, in a preliminary way, that most of these categories were found by the Senate Committee which examined some nine categories as they then were presented in the original Bill, to be unnecessary or at least insufficiently argued for.

As I say, if one is to have exemptions closely defined one also has to have a means of checking on the exercise of that power of declaring, recognising or identifying a document to be exempt. There is a very great difference between identifying a document as falling within one of the exempt categories-in other words, bringing the declared statutory criteria to bear in relation to the document concerned-and identifying the two in a way which is then subject to appeal, in a way which then requires a judgment by the Archives that the category is appropriate to be checked, either by way of internal review as we shall see or by way of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That, of course, is the preferred way of the Senate Committee. But what one has within the scheme of the Bill is a system whereby in relation to three of the categories there can be a simple declaration that documents fall within three categories. In other words, there is a simple declaration by the Minister or an authorised officer that a document falls within categories outlined in clause 33 (1) (a), (b) or (c). These relate to documents or records containing information or matter the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to cause damage to the security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth; information or matter communicated in confidence between internal Australian governments to the Commonwealth, of information or matter the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to cause damage to relations between the Commonwealth and some other government and any State or the Northern Territory. In these three instances conclusive certificates can be issued by the Minister. Here one has a repetition of the defect which has been commented upon in relation to the Freedom of Information Bill.

I reiterate and re-emphasise that we are dealing with documents which are at least 30 years old. We are not dealing with documents currently created. Nevertheless, in relation to them, why not take the matter to an independent tribunal, composed of people of integrity, which could verify that indeed the document contained information or matter which could reasonably be expected to cause damage to the security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth? If a document were so verified no one in this chamber would assert that the document should nevertheless be made available except perhaps under very special and stringent conditions. Why not have such a system-this is the argument of the Senate committee-rather than the conclusive certificates which, as I say, may be issued by the Minister. In other words, what we have here is a situation whereby, in relation to the first three sub-clauses of clause 33 (1), the Government may determine on criteria which are perhaps never really revealed, certainly in a way which is controllable in the sense that they cannot be reviewed, to withhold these documents sought by an applicant though they be 30 years or more in age.

It is rather strange that in relation to these three categories first-mentioned in clause 33 (1) a parallel power resides in the Archives to make its own judgment that documents fall within those categories. Of course, such assessment can be appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; so it is not really the nature of the document or the category which are so important that the Minister himself, or his authorised officer, need issue conclusive certificates. The suspicion must linger in instances in which the Minister is notconvinced that an independent tribunal would reach the same conclusion as the Archives in determining that the documents contained information or matter of the type described. For example if he were persuaded that the Archives had made a proper determination and that the category was indeed applicable, on appeal the exempt status of the document would survive and it would not be available to the applicant in a way which may reasonably be expected to cause damage to the interests set out in clause 33 (1) (a). So the ministerial power to issue conclusive certificates exists concurrently with the ordinary power of the Archives, but the decisions taken in ministerial conclusive certificates are non-appealable. The Senate Committee found, particularly in relation to documents more than 30 years old, that that system of conclusive certificates could not be justified. It is to be said in favour of the wording of clause 33 (1) (a) that there is a harmonising of the language to bring it closer to that of the Protective Security Handbook than was the wording of the original Bill. That change is to be welcomed.

In relation to five of the categories, namely, those referred to in clause 33 (1) (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f), at the Committee stage the Opposition will go into greater detail. It is enough to say that all five categories were considered by the Senate Committee. In respect of none of them was there enough substance or conviction in the arguments put forward by the Minister initially, or by witnesses, to enable the Committee to agree to their presence in the Bill. So, the Senate Committee recommended against five of the 11 categories being included in the Bill. Honourable senators would find that noteworthy. Taken with the other matters I have mentioned, this should enable honourable senators to support the amendment to the second reading motion. The position amounts to the Government's persisting in its determination that these categories should stand, even though the Committee, which took exhaustive evidence, could find no good reason for their being continued.

We then have a series of redrafted categories which deal with the protection of law enforcement procedures. Once again, I would imagine that no one in this chamber would object greatly to measures being taken to ensure that no information or matter which could reasonably be expected to prejudice the enforcement or proper administration of the law in a particular instance became available under the provisions of the Archives Bill. But although there can be agreement in principle in relation to that matter, there can be some dispute as to the wording that might be used in regard to these categories. No doubt that will be spelt out at the Committee stage. It is enough to say that in this new Bill some new categories have been introduced. For example, a document will be exempt from the operation of the Bill when it contains information or matter which could reasonably be expected to prejudice the conduct of an investigation of an offence, or possible offence, against the law or a failure, or possible failure, to comply with the law relating to taxation. That is a completely new provision when compared with the previous Bill.

I believe that another new provision is to be found in clause 33 (1) (h) (i) which exempts a record if it contains information or matter, the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to prejudice the carrying on generally of investigations concerning breaches or evasions of the law. It will be necessary at the Committee stage to look closely at the new extensions of those categories which are concerned to protect procedures dealing with the investigation of suspected breaches of the law and the enforcement of the law. As to the category dealing with the unreasonable disclosure of information relating to the personal affairs of any person, including a deceased person, of course, the Senate Committee agrees with it. There is no question that such a privacy provision ought to be included and is welcome.

The final categories of exemptions deal with records, the disclosure of which would allegedly harm a commercial enterprise or undertaking, or a person in his or her conduct of lawful business activity. What was a single category in the previous Bill has been divided into two categories. Once again, at the committee stage the wording will need to be the subject of close scrutiny.

Another new category is found in clause 33 (2), which provides that a Commonwealth record is an exempt record if it is of such a nature that it would be privileged from production in legal proceedings on the ground of legal professional privilege. I believe that that accords with the Senate Committee's recommendation, although it was meant to supersede other categories and not be additional to them. That, too, will warrant examination at the Committee stage.

I have dealt rather exhaustively with the categories of exemptions in order to alert the Senate to the fact that, depending upon the number of records which might fall within these categories of exemption, we may very well have a major portion of Australia's history not made available to historians and others who have an interest in putting before the community a considered examination of our history insofar as it is contained in documents within the possession of the Commonwealth.

Some 12 categories, including the new category concerning legal professional privilege, are contained in the new Bill, compared with nine in the old Bill. Some five of the 12 were categories that the Committee recommended not be included in the Bill at all. However, whether conclusively determined by the Minister, or merely determined in an ordinary way by the Archives, such decisions being upheld on appeal, quite a range of documents will be exempt from the operation of the Act. Thus, although more than 30 years old, they will not be available. There is, nevertheless, on top of all this, an ability within the Government to make available documents which are exempt. I refer to the special access provisions. In other words, there can be not only accelerated access, whereby an applicant may obtain access to archival documents even though 30 years have not elapsed, but also a special access provision exists in clause 46, whereby the Minister may exercise a discretion to give a particular person access to documents which are otherwise exempt or which at least do not fall within the open access or public access description. At the end of the day, then, yet another discretion is held by the Government whereby the 11 categories can be ignored and the document made available.

The Committee heard evidence which suggested that the community of historians in particular would feel happier if special access were not related to a particular person making an application for such special access. In other words, once the decision is made that special access can be given, there ought to be an immediate attempt on the part of Archives to make such documents available to a wider range of persons than the immediate applicant. There is a residual concern-I would not say anything as strong as 'mistrust'-that one historian, one applicant or one institute, perhaps a university, may be favoured over another in relation to this special access provision. In that respect there is much evidence-I think it is a recommendation of the Senate Committee-that where a special access case is made out the document ought to be made available to a wider range of persons than the immediate applicant. That is contained in chapter 34, paragraphs 6 to 11, of the Senate Committee's report. In particular, evidence was given by Dr Radi, who thought it was discriminatory to grant access to some and not to others. In her opinion, emphasis should be placed upon granting special access to particular documents, not conferring the right upon specific applicants. That led to the recommendation of the Senate Committee that I have outlined.

I turn now to the review and appeal procedures which are contained in clause 40 and subsequent clauses. These have been redrafted in large measure in a way which is to be commended and which harmonises with the Senate Committee's recommendation. For example, where the Archives notifies an applicant that the application has been unsuccessful, the Archives has to make the applicant aware of the internal review provisions which are available to such a disappointed applicant. In particular, there has to be an indication to the applicant of the rights of further internal review and appeal available to him. Further, and in accordance with the spirit of the Senate Committee's report, the Archives has to respond to that initial application within 90 days. That is the maximum limit set by the Bill for a response to an application for access to a document. That period of 90 days can be shortened by way of regulation, and it will be recalled that the Senate Committee thought that the Archives could make an adequate examination of the case of the applicant within 60 days. I take this further provision for a regulation enabling a shortening of the maximum period to be an indication of good faith on the part of the Archives that, once its work routines are established in relation to perhaps a new work load under the statutory structure here being created, regulations will progressively shorten the maximum period within which a response to the application must be made by the Archives. That is to be commended.

Under clause 41 there is an opportunity for a disappointed applicant to seek an internal review of the decision of the Archives. Once again, that is well set out. The provision is not as vague as it appears to be when it says that the Archives has to make the internal review as expeditiously as possible, because under later provisions of the Bill it has to act under constraints which mean it really has to make this review within 14 days of the request for an internal review. If the internal review is still of the same disappointing character to the applicant, namely, that the document is excluded from the purview of the Bill or is an exempt document, the Archives has to state the findings of fact and the reasons for coming to the decision it has come to. On that basis, an appeal may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Clause 43 (2) is the key to the Tribunal's powers. That clause makes it clear, as it ought to, that the onus is on the Archives to establish that the document contain information or matter which brings it within the categories of exempt documents. It is for the Archives to discharge the onus of showing why the decision should be adverse to the applicant. The Tribunal makes a decision completely freshly; it is not bound by any prior determination by the Archives. The Senate Committee found that the Bill had been drawn in a way which made it unclear whether the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, having found that a document was properly categorised as exempt, could nevertheless exercise some sort of discretion and make it available to the applicant. That is not to be the case. The Committee thought it ought not to be the case. Clause 43 (4), a new clause, makes it clear that the Tribunal does not have the power to decide that access be given to a record otherwise determined to be properly categorised as exempt. Nevertheless, even if that discretion is not exercisable by the Tribunal, it is exercisable by the Minister under the special access provisions. The Senate should welcome to some extent new clause 45, which makes it clear, insofar as it was necessary, that the jurisdiction of the Ombudsman to pursue a grievance raised by an applicant is in no way affected or diminished, much less taken away, by the various procedures here legislatively provided for. Some extended activity on behalf of the Ombudsman might be in order, as outlined by Senator Missen in his remarks before dinner.

Finally, may I comment on the role of the Advisory Council. This was lightly touched on by Senator Missen. The functions of the Advisory Council are set out briefly in clause 11. In that clause it is made clear that the Council is envisaged as having a merely advisory role. There will be times when it can take the initiative or can respond to a request by the Minister or the Director-General to give advice, but it is perceived, as I see it, as an advisory body. Indeed, 'advisory' is part of its title. I express my disappointment, which I am sure is shared by other members of the Senate Committee, that the Government has not taken up the Senate Committee's recommendation that this Council, composed of a member of this chamber, a member of the House of Representatives, and 11 other distinguished members of the community, should have an extended, supervisory and monitoring role.

Many functions could very properly be given to such a council. For example, under clause 37 the Director-General may withhold a record otherwise within the open access period because he has judged that to make it available would make its care or its preservation impossible. I think Professor Neale, in evidence, gave an example of some immigration records which, when opened, could fall apart and disintegrate. He did not have the photographic equipment to take photographs of the curved surface of such volumes. In these cases the Senate Committee recommended that a list of the documents, otherwise available in the open access period but for the judgment by the Director-General that they could not be made available for reasons of their care and preservation, should be tabled before the Advisory Council in order for it to monitor and to be aware of this very exceptional and unfortunate circumstance.

Again, the arrangements for determining which documents should be in the open access period-arrangements are to be made between the Director-General and the Minister responsible as to how this determination is to take place-should be in writing and should be tabled before the Council so that as little as possible is not in the public arena as to these arrangements which are of such importance to historians and to others. Likewise, the arrangements for accelerated and special access which are entered into under clause 46 should be in writing and tabled before the Council.

The Director-General, in evidence before the Committee, promised, I think, to make available guidelines under which the Archives operates or hopes to operate in relation to special access and which he thought might form the basis of the regulations which are proposed. Those guidelines never materialised before the Committee. It is that type of guideline which the Committee believes ought to be made known and available to the Advisory Council. Of course, there should be laid regularly before the Council a list of the nature and numbers of documents declared or determined to be exempt.

Finally, we thought, as Senator Missen outlined, that there could be a consultative role and not merely an informed after the event role in relation to the destruction of documents. The destruction of records and documents is so central by way of antithesis to the function of an archival institution that it was thought that lists of documents proposed to be destroyed could well be laid before the Advisory Council to enable it to have some sort of consultative role in the all-important decision to remove such records for ever from the perusal of those who might be interested in our history at some future date.

As I have said, the Opposition welcomes the Bill, providing as it does a statutory basis for the operation of the Australian Archives. I have expressed concern that in very many important respects the Bill is defective in the same way and along the same lines as so many of the provisions and omissions of the Freedom of Information Bill which have been brought to the attention of this chamber. Some further ones peculiar to Archives have been noted by me and, prior to me, by Senator Ryan. Therefore, it is only natural that I should support and call upon other senators to support the amendment moved by the Opposition to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time so that at the end of that motion this chamber can add:

, but the Senate expresses its concern at the failure of the Executive to ensure that the Bill accords with all the recommendations of the reports on the Archives Bill 1978 by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

Those committees gave a great service to this chamber during, I believe, the most exhaustive taking of evidence on Bills of this nature in the history of this Parliament and probably that of many parliaments around the world. It is a matter for concern and regret that so many defects and omissions still remain in respect of a Bill whose introduction in principle by Senator Durack is to be commended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Archives Bill. The administration of archives in Australia has been a development of increasing importance, particularly since World War II. For 30 years the Australian Archives, which used to be known as the Commonwealth Archives Office, has operated in a general pattern in relation to arrangements for records dealing with government business as well as with preserving government records of historical or national value and of significance. Provision is also made for scholars and the public under approved circumstances to engage in research and for the obtaining of information.

SPEECH.PARA: The Archives Bill now before the Senate seeks to preserve the Archives with a statutory basis for its operations. It places the Archives within a department and under a ministerial administration and confers on an officer-in this case a Director-General-certain powers and functions which relate to his statutory authority. As honourable senators understand and appreciate, archives and the disciplines connected with archives are part of an ancient process. When the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was conducting its inquiry into those sections of the Archives Bill which were referred to it, I, as Chairman of that Committee, opened the hearing with a statement, during which I made this observation:

Archives and archival institutions have existed for a long time and probably have their origins in the ancient Greek civilisation. In the fifth and fourth centuries B.C. the Athenians kept their valuable records in the Temple of the Mother of the Gods in the public square of Athens. These records included treaties, laws and accounts of their assembly. The Middle Ages saw a new influence on the character of archival establishments--
I then made this point-

but we are concerned with the development of modern institutions. In France, the United Kingdom and the United States inquiry and legislative action has led to the setting up of archival establishments.
I went on to quote an historian, Professor Charles Andrews, who, in his statement some 40 years ago, said:

No people can be deemed masters of their own history until their public records gathered, cared for and rendered accessible to the investigator have been systematically studied and the importance of their contents determined.
Professor Andrews went on to state:
Among public records and monuments of the past and holding first place in value and importance are public archives.
At the conclusion of my speech on that occasion I said:
Archives therefore become the basis for information and communication services and the importance of an efficient archives infrastructure is emphasised.

Here in Australia several institutions engage in maintaining records and material which are of interest and significance to the Australian community. They include the Australian National Gallery, the Australian War Memorial, the National Museum and the National Library of Australia. The Australian Archives comes into this picture now with its new-found statutory status which will enable it to preserve for this country those records and that material which are of significance and of value to the Australian community.

In relation to the Bill which is before us now I refer to June 1978 when the first Bill in relation to archives was introduced. In the course of a composite speech relating to a number of matters the relevant Minister, referring particularly to the Archives Bill 1978, said that the Bill provided the machinery which would improve the management of the Commonwealth's own records. He pointed out that the proposed legislation replaced existing ad hoc arrangements as well as certain conventions but more importantly it established, he said, firm procedures governing the custody, destruction, retention, storage, conservation and, I think he said this with some emphasis, public accessibility to the vast mass of record material. In the discussion at that time it was recognised that a need for reform was long overdue. Examination of the problems had been undertaken over the years and, as the Minister said at the time, had resulted in a Bill which he thought would commend itself not only to the Parliament but also to the Australian community. In undertaking a process of reform in this regard the Government was concerned in the first instance with the need for efficient administration and availability of the nation's records, documentation and material which might fall, one way or another, within the description of archives.

With the passage of time a greater accumulation of information material had been built up. It had also opened up a wealth of research material of vital interest in almost every profession and discipline that was of some significance to the development of the recorded history of Australia. The Government was concerned that consistent with the claims of national security on the one hand and individual privacy on the other this great national resource of records and of material should be put, to quote the Minister, at the disposal of the public through a network of archival facilities and reference services. Accordingly, the legislation provided for a comprehensive provision for the administration of the records of departments and other agencies in this country. It required, for example, that records be transferred to archival repositories as quickly as possible and furthermore that retrieval services should be provided.

Speaking at the time the Minister said that the provisions of the Bill would be to provide that the function of the Australian Archives should be the custody and management of all Commonwealth records which were not required to be readily available for the ongoing needs of government administration. He defined a Commonwealth record as any record which is the property of the Commonwealth and went on to say that the term did not extend to material in a collection maintained by the Australian War Memorial, the National Library of Australia or the Australian National Gallery. He said that together all of these materials would constitute the archival resources of the Commonwealth and it would be the special responsibility and function of the Archives to care for and maintain those resources. He said that the Archives would also have the function, where appropriate, of encouraging and fostering the preservation and collection of all other archival resources which related to Australian development, property, interests and matters of cultural value. The most significant single function of the Australian Archives, as the Minister said at the time, will be the care and management of Commonwealth records no longer required for Commonwealth use.

Let me explain how my involvement in this matter came about. In September 1978 the Senate sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts certain parts of the Archives Bill which were more particularly related to its work. A great quantity of the Archives Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. When the report was put to the Senate the Government took note of it and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) made his response in due course to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee. The Government accepted, I think, 3 1/2 of the five recommendations which we put down. Three and a half is probably more a phrase of use than it is of accurate description. The Government accepted a number of the recommendations but declined to go on with some others.

The Government accepted our first two recommendations which were quite straightforward and on which we had strong views. They related to the administration of archives, the role of the Director-General and the relationship of the Australian Archives to the efficient working of the Advisory Council. The Committee's fourth recommendation was that clause 28 (2) (a) of the Bill be deleted, but the Government decided that it would not accept that recommendation. During our inquiry we found that some critics of the Bill said that certain elements of clause 28 provided too much latitude for institutions to frustrate the working of the Archives. The effect of clause 28 in our view was that certain records could be exempted from the provisions of the paragraph attached to it. We found that the responsible Minister could determine that a record would not be required and could be transferred to the Archives. In paragraph 5.24 of our report we said:

We believe that the powers conferred on the responsible minister under paragraph 28 (2) (a) of the Bill are unnecessary and tend to frustrate the basic purpose of the legislation. The sole purpose of setting up the Archives is for the impartial management, safe custody and preservation of the archival resources of the Commonwealth.

I emphasise this aspect because earlier in my remarks I drew extracts from speeches and references made on behalf of the Government which supported my argument that the Archives should be available for use, for research, for study and for the whole benefit of the Australian community. It seemed to us then, as it does to me now, that this general theme was cut across by the decision of the Government and that our recommendation was designed with a view to establishing and promoting this theme. I note with regret that the Government has not accepted that particular recommendation. We made our views very clear in recommendation No. 3-we did this in concert with recommendation No. 95 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-which dealt with the matter of the provisions of the Bill relating to the papers for example, of the Governor-General, the Parliament, the courts, the Cabinet and the Executive Council. In response, as I recall it, the Government undertook to make regulations which, it was felt, would meet our situation insofar as Cabinet and Executive Council records were concerned. I refer now to some paragraphs within our report which concern this particular aspect of the Bill. Paragraph 5.11 of the Senate Standing Committee's report stated:
However, in the case of Cabinet and Executive Council records no official explanation has been given for their exclusion from the provisions of Division 2.

We went on to assert that the reasons for their exclusion have been largely left to speculation. Some critics seemed to assume that these records had been included on the grounds of preserving what was described to us as the collective responsibility of Cabinet, as the need to retain the principle that the records of one government should not be made available to its successor, particularly if it were of a different political persuasion, in accordance with the Westminster convention and as not disclosing the deliberations and decisions of Cabinet other than by an official publication.

The Committee in its report said that it may very well be argued that these records were being withheld from the custody of the Archives on the grounds that such records tend to be too sensitive and to be subject to procedures of custody, management and access as provided in the Bill. The Committee in paragraph 5.14 of its report went on to counter the argument in these words:

This argument could be countered on the grounds that it is hard to imagine that any records covered by clauses 19 and 20 would be any more sensitive than those referred to in clause 31, . . . which are considered to be adequately protected by the safeguard measures built into the legislation.
In paragraph 5.15 we said this:

It seems difficult to escape the conclusion that Cabinet and Executive Council records are, after all, records of the executive arm of government, very much akin to records of Commonwealth departments and therefore should be treated like any other Commonwealth records under the provisions of the Bill.
In paragraph 5.16 we conclude:

. . . that while the exclusion of vice-regal, parliamentary and court records is acceptable on the grounds of preserving the traditional independence of these arms of government from the executive, we could find no good reason why this same exemption should apply to the records of the Cabinet and Executive Council.

We went on to recommend that the Bill be amended so as to remove those exemption provisions. I take the opportunity of making those observations insofar as these recommendations were put down as a result of material which had been presented to us and which we of the Senate Committee felt it was important to state to the Senate. In recent times, since our report has been put down, there have been some observations on that section of our report which dealt with the matter of film archives and the role of the National Library as far as film archives are concerned. As honourable senators very well know, I have more than a passing interest in the work of the National Library. I have a very great deal of pride in its film collection and the vast quantity of material which it has in its film collection.

The National Library has organised a large and very valuable collection of Australian and overseas film, and it goes along with some other institutions in this community which have large film archives, one of which of course is the Australian War Memorial. Furthermore, I think it is important to point out that the Australian Archives has been taking films into its custody in repositories throughout this country for very many years now. Each State government, for example, maintains a film collection which is of some considerable archival significance, and the holdings of these many institutions between them make up the film heritage of Australia.

I make the point that there is nothing in the Bill, as I see it, to suggest that this well established position will be altered. The Bill does not prevent other institutions such as the National Library from continuing to acquire, hold and maintain valuable film collections. The Bill has no provisions for the compulsory deposit of such material in the Archives and the collections of the National Library are in any case specifically exempt. A reference to clause 3 of the Bill will point this fact up.

Australian Archives serves as the archives repository for film records of the Administration just as it is the repository, as I have said earlier tonight, for other kinds of government records. The Archives does not accept deposits of film from non-government sources, and what is more, it directs offers of deposit from such sources to appropriate authorities such as the National Library and the State film libraries. The Archives takes custody of films as part of its normal repository services provided for Commonwealth records. In doing this, of course, it is consistent with the practices adopted in other countries. The national archives of the United States, Canada and West Germany all have this function, and it has been carried out in Australia by the Australian Archives for many years.

It is very interesting to point out that the National Library collects published material which is defined in the Copyright Amendment Bill as material offered for sale or hire to the public and beyond this acquires copies of unpublished printed matter, films and sound recording. The role of the Archives as outlined in this Bill is rather different. Archives, unlike a library collection, is the result of the administrative process whereby certain materials accumulate in the course of public business and they are kept to serve either the purpose of the administration which produced them or the public interest in the material insofar as it is valuable from an historic point of view, or interesting, or indeed falls into both categories. In this context it is the duty of the Australian Archives to provide archival services for Commonwealth agencies in a whole range of recorded materials, some of which I have referred to tonight, and of course including the matter of films.

The matter of the Archives Bill is of some significance and the details relating to its implementation are of course of particular importance. I think it is significant that matters related to the Archives Bill have been referred to two important Senate committees, and they have produced a number of recommendations. The inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of course, was a much wider, greater and detailed inquiry than the inquiry carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. Nevertheless, together they have provided a very valuable gathering of opinion and of response from the Australian community and they have made recommendations to the Senate. It is to be regretted that not all of the recommendations have been accepted by the Government because they have been put forward by honourable senators in this place, sitting in Committee and reflecting what the community has told them in response to the invitation so to do.
I am reminded of the quotation of Professor Charles Andrews that I gave right at the beginning of my speech. He stated:
No people can be deemed masters of their history until their public records gathered, cared for and rendered accessible to the investigator . . .
Among public records and monuments of the past and holding first place in value and importance are public archives.
It is the area of public archives with which we are concerned tonight. I give my support to the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been an interesting and valuable debate on the motion for the second reading of the Archives Bill. I am pleased that the Senate is supporting the measure, albeit there have been a number of criticisms of the measure very much along the same lines as the criticisms made of the Freedom of Information Bill. However, it is truly recognised by honourable senators, that this Bill to give a statutory base for the archives of this nation is a most important step forward. It is pleasing that that will be taking place when this measure, it is hoped, becomes law in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has moved an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time in terms that the Senate should express its concern at the failure of the Executive to ensure that the Bill accords with all the recommendations on the Bill that were made by the two Senate committees that have examined it. Honourable senators who have spoken on it, I think, have all been members of those committees. The last speaker, Senator Davidson, was certainly speaking on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. I thought that 3 1/2 out of five was not a bad sort of result to receive from that Committee. Perhaps it is better than the result obtained from the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

The real point is that the matters that have been raised are matters for consideration at the Committee stage rather than during the debate at the second reading stage. The Government has given close consideration to the reports of both committees, as was demonstrated in the response made by me on behalf of the Government in September last year. The terms and tone of the amendment that has been moved by Senator Ryan seem to assume that because a Senate committee recommends a particular change to a Bill, that recommendation must be accepted by all concerned-the Government as well as the rest of the Senate. This is a strange notion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very democratic.

—It is not democratic. The Senate Committee comprised six senators. The Senate comprises 64 senators. Simply because six senators sitting on a committee have reached a certain view is absolutely no reason in itself why the Senate should accept that view. We have been over this sort of thing in relation to other committee reports.
—What is the purpose of the Senate undertaking these investigations?

—There is no more magic in the views of a Senate committee than there is in the views of the Government. The Government has examined the views of the Committee. It has accepted some and has rejected others. Nobody is saying that because the Government takes a view everybody has to agree with it. There is no more reason why, simply because--
—It is a false analogy.

—We have all this excitement. Talk about democracy! Six senators, particularly if Senator Ryan is one of them, have formed a view and the rest of the 58 senators have to accept it! That seems to be the reasoning.
—No, we ask you to consider our recommendations.

—That is not what the honourable senator's amendment says. The honourable senator is saying that the Senate-the other 58 senators, in fact-now have to accept the view of the six senators who have examined the Bill. That is what the amendment to the motion proposes. As far as I am concerned as a senator and as far as the Government is concerned, we are rejecting that notion of the role of Senate committees. I hope that the Senate will reject the amendment because it is expressing a completely false conception of Senate committees and their role. Senate committees perform a most useful purpose. They examine these matters; they put forward their views and it is then for those views to be examined in the Committee of the Whole. There is no reason why the Senate should rubber stamp the views of Senate committees any more than it rubber stamps views put forward by the Government. That is why this amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill should be rejected by the Senate. I hope that it will do so and that the Senate will then move into the Committee of the Whole to examine the proposed amendments on their merits. I hope that this matter can now proceed in that way and that in due course a Bill which is satisfactory to the Senate as a whole will emerge from the debate and consideration.
