TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Committee is: 'That item 9 be noted'.

INTERJECT.PARA: Item 10. Standing Order 68: Introduction of New Business after 10.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Standing Order 68 be amended to read as follows:
68. No new business shall be commenced after the adjournment of the Senate has been first proposed on any sitting day.
Although this matter is set out in the report of the Standing Orders Committee perhaps I should make some introductory remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you don't believe in committee reports.

—I did not say I did not believe in them. I said there is no reason why recommendations of committees should be rubber stamped. Standing Order 68 provides that no new business shall be commenced after 10.30 p.m. This Standing Order has become somewhat obsolete because the Senate now invariably adopts sessional orders which provide that the question for the adjournment of the Senate is put from the Chair at 11 p.m. on broadcast days and 10.30 p.m. on other days. It has been practice to regard the Standing Order as having effect at 11 p.m. on broadcast days. The Standing Orders Committee has recommended that the Standing Order be revised so as to refer to the time at which the adjournment of the Senate is first proposed on any sitting day. The effect of this will be that once the question for the adjournment has been put from the Chair, if that question is negatived and the Senate continues to sit no new business can be introduced after that time unless Standing Order 68 has previously been suspended. The Standing Order will thereby, as the Standing Orders Committee indicates, still provide a safeguard against the introduction of new business when senators may not be expecting new business to be commenced.It is important to remember that apart from the sessional order the only way in which the question for the adjournment of the Senate can be proposed from the Chair is after a motion by or on behalf of a Minister has been moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Item 11. Suspension of Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Standing Order 441 be amended to read as follows:

If any Senator be suspended, his suspension on the first occasion shall be for the remainder of that day's sitting; on the second occasion for seven consecutive days; and on the third or any subsequent occasion for fourteen consecutive days, such suspensions occurring within the same calendar year.
I think that paragraphs 29 and 30 of the report of the Committee are self-explanatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the sentiments of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on this matter. I am wondering about the wording of the proposed Standing Order. Perhaps I am entirely wrong in my interpretation of what it might mean.
—Never.
—That is a considerable act of faith on the part of Senator Chipp. I am indebted to him. The words at the end of the amendment read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . such suspensions occurring within the same calendar year.

It is slightly difficult for me to determine to which words that passage relates. I do not in any way dissent from the Minister's sentiment about what is intended to be done. It might be a good idea if the Standing Orders Committee had a look at it at some subsequent stage and put the interpretation of those words beyond doubt. The words could, of course, relate just to the 14 consecutive days suspensions. I do not think that is intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel that I must oppose the amendment. How tyrannical can we get? When someone commits an indiscretion and says something which justifies his being named, we suspend him. At present, the Standing Order states in relation to suspension:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . on the first occasion shall be for the remainder of that day's sitting; on the second occasion for one week; and on the third or any subsequent occasion for fourteen days, such suspension occurring within the same session.

I do not think what is meant by a session of the Parliament has ever been clearly defined. The explanation seems to be that a session is the period from the inauguration of a parliament until its suspension; it is suggested that sessions may be for three years. I do not think a suspension has ever been interpreted as covering a three-year period. It has been thought that it is meant to end after a period or after a session has ended. However, this amendment reads:

If any Senator be suspended, his suspension on the first occasion shall be for the remainder of that day's sitting; on the second occasion for seven consecutive days; and on the third or any subsequent occasion for fourteen consecutive days, such suspensions occurring within the same calendar year.

If someone commits an indiscretion and warrants naming and suspension, I am not sure of the advisability of depriving the Senate of the suspended senator's capabilities for a period of fourteen consecutive days because for the third time he has found himself in breach of Standing Orders when perhaps there is no justification for such a long sentence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to understand the point you are making about the consecutive days. Are the words '14 consecutive days' different from the existing Standing Order, in your view? Does the word 'consecutive' make a difference?

—Yes, I think it may make a difference. As Senator Button is trained in the art of interpretation, I thought he could tell me what it meant rather than my telling him. I note the difference. On the second occasion a member is suspended for one week. I do not know what that implies when one considers that the Senate sits for three days in one week. If a senator is suspended on the last sitting day of the week I do not know whether the one week's suspension would carry over into the next week. It has not been applied in the Senate in that way. The words 'consecutive days' seem to control the member even when Parliament is not sitting. If a senator is to be suspended for a number of consecutive days, it seems meaningless if Parliament is not sitting. The point I want to make is that the suspension penalty should be based upon the gravity of the accusation or the offence of the member rather than being made mandatory for the occasion especially if there is not going to be a repetition. If someone repetitively offends against the Parliament, obviously we do not have much protection on 14 consecutive days.

SPEECH.PARA: There should be varying degrees of suspension. I do not think that on any occasion we should set a suspension period of 14 consecutive days if someone is concerned sufficiently to offend against the Chair. We are not the sole judges of the conduct of members. Surely the electors are the judges. It does not seem right that the electors of a State of the Commonwealth should be deprived of a representative for 14 days because of his behaviour, although we may think there is some justification for his suspension. Therefore, I oppose the amendment. I do not understand what the present rule is, as Senator Button has pointed out. The present rule states that, on the second occasion, a senator shall be suspended for one week. It goes on:
. . . and on the third or any subsequent occasion for fourteen days, such suspension occurring within the same session.

I do not know what the definition of a session is, but the Committee has accepted a session as being from the commencement of a parliament until the finalisation of a Parliament. Perhaps the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), who is in charge of the matter, could give me some information on what is meant by the word 'session' under the present Standing Orders and what is the difference between the proposed amendment and the present Standing Order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, can I ask how you regard this proposed new Standing Order? Could you give us your view, as Temporary Chairman, or the view of the Clerk or the Usher of the Black Rod, or the view of whoever would prevent the senator coming back into the chamber, on what would happen if a senator were suspended tonight for the third time this sitting? For how many days would he have to stay out?

—Senator Chipp has asked the Chair a question on this matter. Firstly, I should say that the responsibility of the Chair is for the forms of the Senate and for order within the chamber. Secondly, all I can say at this stage, unless I hear anything different from the Attorney-General and his advisers, is that I understood--
—It is not a question for the Attorney-General, Mr Temporary Chairman. This concerns the discipline of the Senate. That is in your hands or the hands of the President.

—All I can say is that, as I understand the language of the report in item 11 concerning the suspension of senators, on the second occasion the suspension would be for seven consecutive days and on the third occasion it would be for 14 consecutive days. That is my understanding of the language used.
—But is that sitting days?
—I understand that it is just calendar days, not sitting days.

—As I understand you, Mr Temporary Chairman, if I were suspended this evening and it was my second offence you or whoever you represent, being the person who would administer this proposed new Standing Order, would permit me to re-enter this chamber next Wednesday morning-tomorrow week?

—The honourable senator would be permitted to re-enter after seven calendar days, as I understand it. So if he happened to be suspended at 10.29 p.m. on a Thursday prior to a recess week, he would be out for only about one minute, as I understand it. Does the honourable senator wish to follow up that matter any further?
—No, Mr Temporary Chairman. You have made it very clear, thank you.

—Surely the Standing Order must refer to consecutive days. If it referred to sitting days and a suspension came at the end of a sitting and the next sitting was not to take place for three or four months, that suspension might even lead to the expulsion of the senator concerned from the Senate, as I understand it. By virtue of the way in which this Parliament sits, the suspension would need to be for seven consecutive days rather than seven sitting days, because seven sitting days could stretch over many weeks.
—That is the situation as I understand it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have now had time to consider this matter. Currently, on the first occasion the suspension is for the remainder of the day's sitting. That is clear enough. The recommended Standing Order provides for the same provision. On the second occasion the suspension is for one week. I take it from your reply to Senator Chipp, Mr Temporary Chairman, that one week could mean one minute. I thought you told Senator Chipp that if his second suspension occcurred tonight it would be until the end of this week but that if it occurred on the last day of a session it would be until the end of that day. A week, then, is a sitting week. A sitting week terminates on the Thursday evening when the Senate rises. The proposal is that on the second occasion the suspension should be for seven consecutive days. If a second suspension occurred on a Thursday, a suspension of seven consecutive days could carry through into the following week and the suspension would operate during that time. I am concerned about that part of the Standing Order which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . or any subsequent occasion for 14 days, such suspension occurring within the same session.
My main concern is: What is a session? The report of the Standing Orders Committee states:
This Standing Orders has remained unchanged since the time when sessions of the Parliament seldom lasted more than a year.
Obviously, at one time sessions lasted a year. The report continues:
Now that sessions are apt to extend for up to three years . . .

Therefore, I take it that a session is the period of a Parliament. Under the proposed new Standing Order, on the third or any subsequent occasion the suspension is for 14 days. If after committing three offences a senator breaches the rules of conduct and commits an indiscretion at any time in the three years, if I am making a correct interpretation, he will be out for 14 days. We are now altering that provision to apply to suspensions occurring within the same calendar year. If in the autumn session I commit an offence against the Chair and am named and suspended on two occasions and in the Budget session in August I commit another indiscretion which justifies suspension, I will be out for 14 days under this interpretation of the period. The offences would occur in the same calendar year. The explanation in the report states that the present rule seems harsh. I have never known the present Standing Order to be interpreted to mean that the session was the life of the Parliament, but it seems that the Standing Orders Committee was of the opinion that the session was the life of the Parliament. I take it that the autumn and spring sessions of this Parliament are the periods to which the Standing Order applies. I would seek some enlightenment on that matter. If an offender's first and second suspension occurred in the autumn session and his third suspension occurred in the spring session, would he be suspended for 14 days during the spring session?

TALK.START.PARA: -I will endeavour to enlighten Senator Cavanagh. As I understand the situation, in the olden days Parliament was prorogued every 12 months and there was subsequently a re-opening of Parliament. Consequently, these rules applied for the 12-month period. But in recent times, of course, a session of Parliament has lasted a full three years. The object of this exercise is to return to the old situation in which the Standing Order applied to a 12-month period.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, might I add something to what has been said by Senator Maunsell? As a member of the Senate Standing Orders Committee and following what was said in response to the remarks of Senator Cavanagh I point to the statement on page 619 of the fifth edition of Odgers's Australian Senate Practice, which statement was drawn to the attention of the Standing Orders Committee when the Committee was considering this matter. It states that a session of parliament begins with an official opening by the Governor-General and ends either by prorogation or by dissolution of the House of Representatives. So in fact the whole life of the Parliament is the session of the Parliament. The periods about which Senator Cavanagh has spoken-the autumn session and the Budget session-are really sessional periods but the session is deemed to be, as I understand it, the whole period of the Parliament. Under the existing Standing Order, a person could be suspended on the first occasion for the remainder of that day's sitting, on the second occasion for one week and on the third or any subsequent occasion for 14 days, over a period of three years. Certainly, I think one of our colleagues has been suspended for at least one week in the time that I have been here. It was felt that that action was a bit hard on the State that he represented and that the period should be brought back to a calendar year. The purpose of writing in the words 'consecutive days' is to differentiate between non-sitting days and sitting days. For instance, if a person were to be suspended today for seven consecutive days, today being the first day of his suspension, he would be entitled to take his place again in the chamber next Tuesday.
—Next Wednesday, wouldn't it be?
—No, today is Tuesday, is it not? Today would be the day on which he is suspended.
—That is counted as one day.

—That is counted as one day. If a person were suspended for a period of 14 consecutive days he would be entitled to take his place here in the chamber on next Tuesday week, today fortnight, provided of course that the suspension happened within the period of the calendar year. I think that is quite simple. It sets out the matter in plain language and I think it should be supported by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the matter raised by Senator Cavanagh querying what constitutes a session has opened up a Pandora's box. I am thinking now of the employment of Senate attendants who are employed as sessional attendants. An interpretation was given by Senator Maunsell that in the old days a session was for 12 months but that in recent times it has been for three years. Perhaps the Senate attendants who have been employed as sessionals will have a case against the Parliament for payment for the whole of the three years, even though they have not worked for the whole of that time. That is something which might be taken up unless we clarify the word 'sessions'. Perhaps to get over that problem we ought to call sessions the autumn period and the Budget period rather than the autumn session and the Budget session if we are to use double standards so far as sessions go. I do not want to build up the hopes of some of the Senate attendants who have been paid as sessionals just for the autumn period and the Budget period and have them think that they might have some claim for retrospective payment for the whole of the time which is termed to be a session, that is, from the opening of Parliament until the prorogation of Parliament. That is something that needs to be looked at.

SPEECH.PARA: But I am quite happy with and support the re- commendation of the Committee because on most occasions when a senator is suspended his actions are not premeditated. If they were, I suppose he could use these new recommendations to his advantage. If he wanted to be suspended to incur the wrath of a Minister he could do as Senator Maunsell pointed out a while ago, that is, at the end of a week's session on a Thursday night, he could be suspended for one minute. That would constitute a day's suspension. On the next occasion, say, when the Senate is about to rise for a week's recess, he could be suspended again on a Thursday night. He would serve his week's penalty when the House was not sitting. If he wanted to be suspended again he could do so when the House rises for a fortnight just as we have had a fortnight's recess for Easter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or in June.

—Yes. So he could be suspended on three occasions but his actual sessional suspension would not be for more than three minutes. That is if his actions were premeditated. But on most occasions it does not happen that way. Usually when a person is suspended it happens because something that he has not thought of arises and tempers become frayed and then he is ordered out of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see something recommended by the Senate Standing Orders Committee on another matter. There have been occasions in the other place-I am not aware of any in this place-where a member has refused to leave the chamber. Of course there are no arms in that place with which to eject such members so the sitting of the House has to be suspended. But of course in this place the Usher of the Black Rod is armed with a weapon of war. As I have said, I have always been afraid of what will be the outcome if a senator sits tight after the Usher of the Black Rod has been asked to escort him from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did once.
—Yes, but we did not have the Wilkinson sword here then. I have always been worried whether it would be brought into use.
—Why don't you show a bit of courage and find out?

—I might do that. Perhaps the next time the Standing Orders Committee is looking at some amendments to the Standing Orders it will look at that matter to see whether something can be written into the Standing Orders to the effect that the sword is to be used only on ceremonial occasions and not to be used to eject a person from this chamber, otherwise we might have a compensation case on our hands if a person were to be injured. I am quite happy to support the recommendations in clause 11 relating to the suspension of senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again to make a plea for the Committee to have another look at this matter. I propose as an amendment that the Committee be asked to have another look at it. Senator McLaren's remarks about the sword made me afraid as to what would happen if the sword were put into operation.
—Senator Cavanagh, may I suggest that it be noted that the Committee look at the language. This is what you are referring to, is it not?

—Yes, Mr Temporary Chairman. I am not opposed to the period of sentence for the offence. I think the justification, the reason for the Speaker's naming or the President's naming a member is a statement made in an emotional outburst in discussion. I think on only a few occasions does the situation occur whereby a person feels justified in using harsh words against some people against whom he should not be using harsh words and under parliamentary Standing Orders is not prepared to withdraw and must suffer the penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always accepted the view that a session comprised the period of the spring sitting or the autumn sitting. The previous Clerk, Jimmy Odgers, is the authority on what 'a session' means and unless we can contradict his words, a session is the whole period of the Parliament. I suggest that, while the suggested altered Standing Orders make it easier on a member or less severe on a member, the penalty imposed is too long a period. If a member offends on two occasions in the autumn session, goes home in May and comes back in August and offends a second time, to subject him then to 14 days' suspension, I think, is too harsh. He may be in a stage of rehabilitation in that he did not want to offend but something just slipped through and he did so. But there will be the loss to the Senate of his capabilities for 14 days. After that long a period the penalty seems to me to be too harsh. I agree with the proposed penalty. If we want to alter it, using the words Senator Douglas McClelland has used in accepting Odgers's interpretation of what is a session, then we make it for a sessional period. I think Senator Douglas McClelland said that a spring session comprised a sessional period. I think we should be using those words. If a member offends during that period of the sitting on the third occasion he should be out for a week. But I think on each occasion when we reassemble there should be a reappraisal of the situation, there should be a fresh start in that the member starts to incur penalties again, but not because of things he has said. I think to say that a member should be penalised for 14 days in February, say, of this year because of something he said in October of last year is too harsh a penalty for any member to have to pay for a trivial offence. It is not a question of his committing a crime. It is possibly just a question of his indiscretion in the language he has used. I ask the Committee to have another look at these words 'sessional period' or the 12 calendar months, a calendar year, to see whether we should not use the term 'sessional period'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cavanagh, are you so moving or are you asking that what you have said be noted and that the Standing Orders Committee seek a clearer definition of what is meant by the word 'session'?
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I defer to your greater wisdom in the use of words, and ask that my remarks be noted.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Item 12. Other Matters.
Motion (by Senator Durack) proposed:
That item 12 be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose an amendment to item 12 which would have the effect of recommending to the Committee that motions need not be seconded. Standing Order 123 and Standing Order 140 are the apposite Standing Orders. Standing Order 123 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Motion not seconded shall not be further debated.
That Standing Order falls within Chapter XIV-Motions and Questions. Standing Order 140, which is part of Chapter XV-Amendments, states:
An Amendment proposed but not seconded shall not be further debated.
Two other Standing Orders relate to this question. Standing Order 266, which is part of Chapter XX-Committees of the Whole Senate, states:
A Motion made in Committee need not be seconded.
Standing Order 409, which is part of Chapter XXXIV-Conduct of Senators and Rules of Debate, states:

It shall be competent to a Senator, when he seconds a Motion or Amendment or moves an Order of the Day, without speaking to it, to address the Senate on the subject of such Motion, Amendment, or Order of the Day, at any subsequent period of the Debate.

It appears that Standing Order 123 has been in existence since the year dot. It is obviously preferable that any motion placed before a meeting have a seconder. It is important that the proposer have his argument supported by another person or other persons. Obviously, the Standing Orders recognise this because Standing Order 409 enables the seconder of the motion to defer speaking to it, presumably until after other senators have spoken in opposition to the motion. Then the seconder may address himself to the motion, giving due consideration to the points raised in opposition to it. That helps the debate along and assists the consideration of the matter.

However, it seems eminently unfair that the Standing Orders should not have regard to the current situation in the Senate. Standing Order 123-in this I am subject to correction-was a part of the Standing Orders when the Senate was not the party chamber that it is at present. Naturally, a number of senators of independent mind were present in the early days after Federation. Under those circumstances it would have been necessary for the debates in the Senate to proceed normally in accordance with the procedures set out in the standing orders for any meeting. However, at present the Standing Orders enable any honourable senator except me to place a matter before the chamber and have it deliberated upon. I do not think that that is fair. I specifically point out to the Government that there ought not to be a situation in which those who have voted for me cannot have taken to the floor of the chamber a matter which is of significance to them. That is particularly so in regard to giving notice of a motion on matters which may be very important to those electors. I can certainly place a notice of motion before the Senate. If it is called 'not formal' it goes to the bottom of the Notice Paper. When the matter comes up for debate under General Business, it cannot proceed unless I am assured of a seconder to my motion. I do not think it is fair that an honourable senator should not be able to have a matter of substantial importance considered and deliberated upon to a conclusion. Therefore I propose an addendum to Item 12:
That Standing Order 123 be amended to read:
A Motion need not be seconded-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —May I suggest, since there is a motion before the Committee, that the honourable senator move that the following words be added to the motion that Item 12 be noted:

INTERJECT.PARA: but the Committee requests the Standing Orders Committee to reconsider the Standing Orders relating to the seconding of motions and amendments in the light of suggestions made during this debate.
I believe that is consistent with what has previously happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those words are eminently reasonable. I so move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and strongly support what Senator Harradine has said. I feel sure that in light of the generosity of the Committee tonight and the great number of honourable senators who are in the chamber listening to the debate, someone would have seconded the amendment had I not done so. However, the chances are that it may well not have been seconded. I speak as the leader of a small party in this Senate. After 30 June it will not be a small party; it will consist of five senators. I agree with everything that Senator Harradine has said, but I would like him to know that the situation does not apply only to independent senators. It could easily apply to a small party such as the Australian Democrats. For example, Senator Mason and I have on the Notice Paper what we believe to be fairly important notices of motion, as has Senator Harradine. We have been here on Thursday nights but sometimes, as you know, Mr Temporary Chairman, the business takes an interminable time to get through this place and on other occasions it goes through very quickly. It way well be that one of those notices of motion in my name will be called on when Senator Mason is not in the chamber, and it could lapse for want of a seconder if the rest of the Senate wanted to play it hard. I know that does not happen often, but it could happen.

SPEECH.PARA: If we roll notices of motion off the tongue they might not sound important, but here again I support Senator Harradine. A random look at the Notice Paper shows that Senator Mason, Senator Harradine and I have placed on the Notice Paper issues which are not unimportant. For example, Notice of Motion No. 3 in my name concerns the inadequacy of the existing insurance and/or compensation arrangements in the event of a natural disaster. Senator Harradine has one which states, in part:

That the Senate is of the opinion that 1981, being the International Year of Disabled Persons, would be an appropriate occasion for the Federal Government to monitor very carefully the way in which its $1,000 million contribution to Australian hospitals is expended in the care and treatment of disabled persons.

No one could say that that is not of fundamental importance. I have a notice of motion which states that the Senate is of the opinion that no legislation for plant breeders' rights should be introduced until there has been full public discussion. Senator Mason has a most important one which states, in part:
That a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report upon all aspects of the civil defence program against nuclear attack . . .

Senator Mason also has one on the question of 2,4,5-T and its related problems. He also has an extraordinary important one concerning the agreement to allow the United States to land its B52 aircraft in Darwin. I have another one concerning the setting up of a select committee of the Senate to inquire into animal welfare in Australia. All of those are important matters. Standing Orders 123 and 140 have been supported by the Standing Orders Committee and, as they now read, those matters could not be debated in the Senate unless all three of us could get seconders. I say through the Chair to Senator Douglas McClelland, an eminently fair-minded person, that I cannot understand how the Standing Orders Committee could allow to prevail a situation whereby for want of a seconder those important matters might not be debated by the Senate. We could well have a recurrence of the Senator Negus phenomenon. He was elected to the Senate on virtually a single issue-the abolition of death duties. Whether one liked him or agreed with the issue upon which he had been elected was irrelevant; he became a democratically elected senator. Are we to have a Standing Order which would prevent another Senator Negus from speaking in the Senate and from putting the views of a number of electors simply because he could not get a seconder? For those reasons the Australian Democrats strongly support the motion moved by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to the amendment. I feel that if it is carried it will pave the way for abuse of the Senate's time, particularly on Wednesdays, when one senator, no matter whether other senators think his notice of motion is worth while, will get half an hour on air to move a motion and to talk on any subject which he thinks may help him in the political arena. Senator Harradine said that he is the one who would be disfranchised because the Australian Democrats have two senators at present and after 30 June will have more and because the Government parties and the Australian Labor Party have enough senators to support a worthwhile motion. If Senator Harradine brings forward a motion which is worth while and which one other senator thinks is worth while and worthy of debate, he will get a seconder. I feel that, if this amendment is accepted, every Wednesday we will witness a motion being brought forward for the benefit of Senator Harradine and nobody else and that he will get air time.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the present Standing Orders there are plenty of opportunities for him to bring forward matters of importance in the Senate. He can give notice of a motion which will then go on the Notice Paper. Senator Chipp has said that he and Senator Mason have many notices of motion on the Notice Paper, but I have many there too, and it is at the whim of the Government whether they ever come on for debate. But at least they are there. On the first reading of money Bills in this place every senator has the opportunity to speak for a full 30 minutes on a Wednesday and for 60 minutes on a non-broadcast day on any topic he or she chooses. If a senator does not want to do so then, we have an adjournment debate every night that the Parliament sits.

TALK.START.PARA: —A forum for injustice.

—That is right. Every senator has an hour in which to speak on that occasion. Unlike the other place, where any member at any time can move that another member be no longer heard, once a senator is on his feet in this place he cannot be interrupted to be sat down. In my view, there are plenty of opportunities for senators to put their points of view, and I often take advantage of those opportunities. I feel that if this amendment is carried and the Standing Orders Committee agrees to it, we will see Senator Harradine, particularly on Wednesdays, bringing forward many matters from which he thinks he will get some political kudos. If a matter he wants to bring forward is worthwhile, he will certainly get a seconder. As I said earlier, I am opposed to the amendment.

—Senator McLaren's statements are totally unwarranted. That was not the purpose of my making the suggestion. For him to suggest that if the Standing Orders are amended in the way that has been suggested the avenue will be open for me to move motions on Wednesdays is just poppycock.
—You can now, anyway.

—Of course. One can speak on Wednesdays. I do not seem to get on the speakers' list on Wednesdays and I suppose that that will remain the case, having regard to arrangements between the Whips. There are ways of overcoming that which may have to be considered, but this is certainly not the way to do it. Senator McLaren also made the point that senators have plenty of opportunity to speak, but that does not get to the point that I made. Of course we have plenty of opportunities to speak. But to what purpose? I know through many a long year of experience in the trade union movement that one does things by motion and amendment; one does not talk for the sake of talking. I am suggesting that if one wants something done one moves a substantive motion. In my case, that cannot be done if the parties decide that there will be no seconder if Senator Harradine moves a motion. Then this chamber could not deliberate in a substantive way on an issue which I wished to bring before the Senate. As I said, that would disfranchise the people who elected me.

—Senator Harradine said that if his amendment is not carried he will be prevented from moving a motion and having it deliberated upon. If he could not get a seconder to his motion he would know what would be the fate of his motion; if it were put to the vote he would not get enough people to support him. On the other hand, he has mentioned his many long years of experience in the trade union movement. I am of the opinion that, in the trade union movement in which he has been involved, if he moved a motion at any meeting and could not get a seconder his motion would lapse. I think the same thing would happen at branch meetings of Senator Chipp's party. If some member moved a motion and could not get a seconder the chairman would immediately say that the motion lapsed for the want of a seconder. That is what happens in this place. If we were to amend this Standing Order to allow a motion to be debated even if it were not seconded we would be operating in about the only public forum in the community in which one is able to do that.
