—I listened to what Senator Harradine and Senator Chipp said about this matter. I am not a member of the Senate Standing Orders Committee and I do not know what factors were taken into account by it in forming the opinion which is expressed in item 12, but I must say that I feel that there is a lot of merit in the matter which Senator Harradine and Senator Chipp raised. There is a lot of wisdom in having these matters further considered. Senator Harradine's proposal is not, as I understand it, that we make the decision now but that it be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for it to consider the matters which have been raised. Maybe these matters were considered-I do not know-but in any event very strong views have been expressed by two senators who have had the experience of being in a special position in the Senate in regard to this Standing Order. I think that these special considerations ought to be examined by the Committee, and I support the amendment to the motion.

—I wish to speak very briefly. Senator McLaren has said that if a motion is not worth seconding it is not worth debating. I do not believe that a motion can be spoken to without a seconder. Therefore, it would not be clear as to what the motion was all about and what were the reasons for moving it if it were not seconded and debated. I believe that any senator who is elected to this place is elected by a large number of people. Therefore, I have considerable sympathy with the amendment. I would like to see it carried. I am delighted that the Minister--
—This is the first time in four years that you have agreed with me.
—Maybe I am wrong then. I have thought about this matter very clearly and I wonder whether Senator Chipp might withdraw. It might make it easier for me to vote for the amendment.

—For the benefit of some senators who have come into the chamber since this discussion started I shall read the amendment proposed by Senator Harradine. The proposal is that item 12 be noted with the addition of certain words, and those words are: 'but the Committee requests the Standing Orders Committee to reconsider the Standing Orders relating to the seconding of motions and amendments in the light of suggestions made during this debate'.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of the motion for the first reading of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill to raise the matter of the Government's immigration program and its consequences for Australia. The Government's stated policy on immigration is to increase the number of migrants to a considerable extent past the point of necessity for purely humane reasons. If I may quote, it has been said:

SPEECH.PARA: With Great Britain and the Republic of Ireland as the main source of migrants, Australia's migrant intake this year is likely to reach one million for the first time since 1973-74. In the September quarter alone inflow of skilled tradesmen was up 40 per cent, arrivals of skilled metal and electrical tradesmen were up 46.5 per cent. Total arrivals in the quarter rose from 17,701 to 23,614.

The Government is talking about bringing one million extra people into this country, with Australia suffering the highest unemployment it has ever known, with the Government doing precious little about training or retraining the unemployed people who already live in Australia, with the Federal Government providing less money for education so that youngsters go into the work force with even lower qualifications than they had previously, with less money for housing, even though in some areas of Australia, such as the area around Melbourne in Victoria, housing is at a premium because the costs have become so high.

Australia used to go shopping in Europe for its needs as far as skilled tradesmen are concerned. We have taken that lazy attitude year after year from the end of the Second World War. It was easy to go over there and shop for the sort of skills we needed for the sort of industries we had. But now it is obvious when Australia goes shopping that people in Europe are not all that keen about coming to Australia. Why should they come to Australia, uproot their families, come halfway across the world, leave behind the families and the friends they have grown up with and loved when wages out here are no better than they are in Europe? Social services are much better in Europe than they are here. Chances of improvement and chances for their children are much better in Europe than they are here. We find that we cannot buy what we need in Europe, and we go to other parts of the world where people are perhaps less qualified. We bring them out here and in my opinion we treat them as less than human because they are less qualified. In many instances they have had less education than the migrants we may have had in other years. They are at a greater disadvantage when we bring them half way across the world and do precious little for them except to use them as a threat to the work force that already exists in Australia, forcing it to accept worse conditions and worse pay because there is a longer line of unemployed outside the factory gates.

At the moment we have a Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who goes overseas and makes spurious statements about human rights and about how people should be treated. Yet he allows us to take in people from less fortunate parts of the world and then do very little to provide them with a better way of life than they had in the country from which they came. These people who come into Australia with little skill and little background and very little by way of backup are forced to live close to the cities in Australia because they do not have any money for transport. They cannot pay the extraordinary price that we now have to pay for petrol. There is no public transport and so they are forced to live in the inner areas of our cities. I shall speak about Melbourne, which is an area which I know well. In the inner Melbourne area, for instance, at one high school, in the enrolment, 75 per cent of the children come from non-English speaking backgrounds. They get no support in that area. They need a good education if they are to hold their own in the work force and in the community today. They have extraordinary problems in these inner suburban schools in Melbourne. For instance, the 1979 enrolment figures of one school show that of the numbers of students in the school, 29 per cent came from single parent families; 6 per cent came from families where the males were unemployed; 28 per cent came from families which live on pensions; 21 per cent came from families which were on maintenance of some sort; 67 per cent were migrant children; 33 per cent lived in flats, and in those areas they would be housing commission flats-enormous, high, grey cold areas in which to live; 43 per cent came from families where both parents worked; and 39 per cent had lived in their present home for less than three years, so they were mobile. The numbers were continually turning over.

If we have people who do not speak the language, who live in a less than well equipped area, who are very dependent on finding a job to keep themselves, and their families in many instances, then we need to put them into areas where they can get some sort of background and education and some sort of skills with which to go out into the community. They come from economically disadvantaged areas in the first place; yet the schools, the only area they have to rely on, do less than well by them to the point where in this particular school I am talking about, Collingwood high school, in 1980, due to staff shortages, there were 64 students in science classes and over 60 students in mathematics classes. The science classes were conducted in a laboratory which was designed to accommodate 20 students, although over 60 students had to fit into it.

Despite the massive increase of Indo-Chinese students over the past 18 months in that school, there was only one additional migrant English teacher appointed. That made a total of four migrant English teachers in a school where 75 per cent of the children came from a non-English speaking background. In order to provide the intensive instruction for students requiring remedial work they needed an additional five English teachers for years seven to nine and they needed an additional English teacher for each of the years 10 and 11 where no additional assistance could be given. None of those additional special migrant teachers were made available in that area. What sort of future is there for those children in that area? Their parents find it difficult to find work, and will find it increasingly difficult to find work. Their children will find it difficult to get the qualifications that they will need to find work.

In another school not very far from the Collingwood high school, Spensley Street primary school, 43 per cent of the children are from a non-English speaking background. At the Fitzroy high school, again less than a mile away from the other two schools I have mentioned, 80 per cent of the children come from non-English speaking backgrounds. But the story in all of those schools is always the same. There is no staff to deal with their special problems; there is no staff to deal with the fact that they do not speak the language; and there is no staff to deal with the special problems that migrant children have of fitting into our community. There is no staff because there is no funding and there is no funding because this Federal Government, although it brings these migrants into Australia, does not take its responsibilities down to that level and provide the funding that is needed. Subjects such as science and mathematics are reduced in these schools. The number of children who can take those subjects is reduced by anything up to 63 per cent. Yet we know that in the work force that we have today, if children are to find a secure future they need to study science and mathematics. Australia is going out shopping for skilled tradesmen because while we have this extraordinarily high unemployment, we also have an extraordinary lack of skilled tradesmen. It would appear that we cannot train our own children in those areas because they have not got sufficient educational background to allow them to be trained in the specialist areas. So we are going round and round in circles. Why are we bringing people to Australia when we do not provide them with the wherewithal to look after themselves and to be independent. We have a government which likes to stand up and talk long and lovingly about people being independent, about people taking up their own battles, and about people fighting for themselves. But we tie people's hands behind their backs because in these instances we do not give them the sort of help and backing that they need. These children in these schools are mainly migrant children. They are never going to be able to get jobs that increasingly need the sorts of skills that they are not being taught, let alone being taught to speak English which, after all, in an English speaking country, is quite necessary. Because they have not got the skills, because they cannot obtain the jobs, they are reduced to a position where they have to take welfare.

We have various bodies and government members in Australia complaining bitterly about the amount of money that is spent on welfare in this country today, but we do precious little to get people out of the position where they have to take welfare. In other areas, Australia has postured as caring about people who in so many parts of the world today are forced to take the status of refugee. May I cite to the Senate the story of a man who, in the days of the last war in the Lebanon area, when Australia at one stage declared that Lebanese people could be declared refugees, obtained permission to come to Australia as a refugee. He was married and he had two children. In order to get permission to be accepted as a refugee he had to go from Lebanon to Cyprus to get the necessary papers. While he was away in Cyprus getting those papers, his wife was killed. He found that out when he returned to Lebanon. He decided nonetheless to take his children to a new land and start afresh. He had some relatives in Australia, so he came out with his two small boys, planning to live with his sister. When he got here he found that because of her family situation that was not very practical, so he set up house on his own with his two little boys. Of course he had to go to work to earn his living. Because he was away so much of the time, his two boys got into trouble and became hard to control, to the point where a kind and benevolent government took his two boys away from him and put them into a home. This upset him. It would not be putting too fine a point on it to say that this broke his heart because these were his only children; he had hoped to make a new life for them and he now felt he had failed.

After some little time he felt he could no longer bear to have his children away from him because they were lonely, afraid and unable to understand why they should be locked up in a strange place away from their father. So he decided to take his two boys home, get a part time job and try to manage. For a little time he did manage but honourable senators can imagine the sort of money that he was able to earn these days in part time work. It does not pay the sorts of rents that people have to pay and does not pay for the food, clothing and transport for members of a family. To make things worse, he found that he was going blind. That made it even harder for him to find jobs that he could do.

This man is now in a position in which he has to keep two growing boys. He has to put up with the fact that he is going blind and that he cannot find work. The only offer this Federal Government makes to him is to put him on the special benefit. Those of us who have unfortunate people coming through our offices every week know how small the special benefit is these days and how hard it is for those on this benefit to manage. I have spoken to the social workers in the area who are at their wits end to know what to do with this man. Up to this point in time, he has not been in this country long enough to qualify for a pension. The only thing a generous Australian government will give him is the special benefit. Social workers have told me that they spend three days of every fortnight begging for food vouchers for him, begging for special payments from this group or that group to keep this man and his two boys going.

I would have thought that a country that was big enough to offer people refuge and say 'we will accept that you need refuge from the country in which you were born and in which you have grown up; come to our country', might at least offer a little more than that and might at least say: 'You are here; you have started a new life; your two children at least are entitled to a good start'. But we do not. We hide behind the Act that states that unless a person has been here for five years unfortunately we cannot do anything for him. So that man has to put up with watching his two boys grow up in those terrible circumstances. I think it is appalling that Australia postures around the world as a humane country. We say that we care and that we are offering refuge but we then leave people in these insidious positions.

I wonder where this Government thinks these million people it intends bringing out here in the next 12 months will live. All of us, not just those who live in the cities, should be aware that the cost of housing in city areas is climbing at astronomical rates. Houses cost extraordinary prices, the sort of price that puts them outside the reach of the ordinary working man and certainly outside the reach of the family with children. Public housing to which one might think these people may go is becoming harder and harder to find. There is less public housing because less money is being made available for it and in this respect the Federal Government is responsible. The Federal Government has cut and is proposing to cut even further the amount of money it makes available for public housing. Of course, private enterprise, which always prides itself on its enterprise, does not enter into the field of providing housing for people who do not have high incomes. It is only interested in building extraordinarily luxurious houses for people who can pay rents that look like telephone numbers. What housing is left, generally is of an old dilapidated, run-down variety. By now, because of the housing shortage, the rents have been pushed up to extraordinarily high levels.

The Victorian Government is proposing to put the money it gets for housing from the Federal Government into rehabilitating boarding houses because it sees that there is a need for single people and especially young single people to find some sort of housing. Of course there is, but when that money goes into that sort of housing, who is going to provide the housing for families, young families, migrant families and people who are desperately trying to find a place to live and to start their lives anew? When a million of them will be pouring into Australia, it makes one shudder at the sorts of pressure this will put on the housing situation in some of the bigger cities of Australia. In Victoria we are in the ludicrous position of having to pay more in interest on the money we receive from the Federal Government for housing to this point than we will receive from the Federal Government for housing in the next 12 months. I think it is time that some rational view was brought to bear on housing by the Federal Government. Are we going to bring people into Australia and expect them to set up tents? Are we going to get into a situation in which we will have humpies on the river bank again? Up to this point in time we have forced Aboriginal people all over Australia into that sort of housing. We have never taken a realistic attitude about that although we do say in forums around the world that we understand that one of the necessities for good health and for any sort of proper living conditions is that people should be provided with clean water and decent shelter. All I can say is that unless the Government provides a lot more money for housing, many people will have very indecent forms of shelter and they will be very lucky if they have access to clean water. Of course, the people who will suffer are the people who are ill-prepared to go into the work force, the people who will be unemployed and who have little money. In many areas, this will be the migrant population.

In this ill-considered application of a migrant policy, it is not just the young who are not getting an education. It is not just the people of employable age who are not going to have the skills or the jobs to keep themselves and their families. There is a group of elderly migrant women who are treated very much less than as equals and humans by a very inhuman Federal Government. When one applies for citizenship there is a rule that the applicant or the spouse must be able to speak English. If the husband is alive and speaks English, the wife can apply for and be granted citizenship. But, as has been said so often in many places, women tend to live longer than men and there is a large number of elderly migrant women in Australia whose husbands have died who have not learnt to speak or write English and who are in fact illiterate in both their home country language and the English language. These migrant widows are illiterate in both languages. Some of them have been here a lot longer than, say, 10 years but as they have never learnt to speak the language they are not eligible for citizenship. They do apply to become citizens because they want the comfort of being an Australian citizen, they want the comfort of an Australian passport and they feel more secure when they confront the Department of Social Security if they can show that they are indeed Australian citizens. Quite a number of these people have applied for citizenship. The problem is that there does not really seem to be a pattern of acceptance. Some women apply, apply again and apply again but they are knocked back by the Department and told that they are not eligible. In other instances some apply and do get accepted as citizens. Throughout the migrant community there is an unease about whether one can be accepted as a citizen and about the standards that are applied in this circumstance when one applies to become an Australian citizen. Many of these people have applied to come to Australia.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Anzac Day Parade-Australian Capital Territory Motor Traffic Ordinance-Delegated Legislation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, for the sake of the public record, I wish to correct some very serious misrepresentations which have been put forth in the media and, I am very distressed to say, by a Minister of the Government concerning events that took place in Canberra on Anzac Day. Honourable senators will no doubt be aware of the coverage that has been given in the national media through both the Australian Broadcasting Commission and commercial television of the Anzac Day march in Canberra. The impression has been given to viewers and readers all over Australia that the Anzac Day march in Canberra was disrupted by a group of women who, it was claimed, were protesting against the Anzac Day ceremony, their protests centering around women who were the victims of rape in war.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very distressed by these reports, firstly because they are wrong, and secondly because they have come about partly as a result of statements made in public by a Government Minister. I am referring to the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman. I say at the outset-I think any objective record of the events on Saturday will support what I am saying, and, of course, such objective records do exist-that there was never at any stage any intention by a group of women organised loosely under the title 'Women Against Rape in War' to disrupt the Anzac Day ceremonies. That was never at any stage the intention and, indeed, there was no disruption of the Anzac Day march in Canberra. I notice that honourable senators are looking surprised. There was no disruption of the Anzac Day march. Any person participating in that march, any person viewing that march-I understand the honourable senator who is occupying the chair this evening viewed the march because he was present in a representational capacity-will be able to confirm what I am saying.

The Anzac Day march in Canberra was not disrupted. What happened was quite different, and I shall give a very brief account of what actually happened. A group of women in Canberra last year sought to join the Anzac Day march in order to draw attention to women who were the victims of rape in war. They were not allowed to do this. A number of them were arrested under existing local legislation. Charges were subsequently dropped. This year a group of women decided that as the charges had been dropped there was no legal obstacle to them participating in the Anzac Day ceremony in what they, as citizens living in a democratic society, considered to be an appropriate and special way for them to do so. They decided to form a group and join in the march with other organisations such as the various returned soldiers groups, Boy Scouts, the Girl Guides and so on. They decided that they would march for a specific reason very much in tune with the spirit of the Anzac Day ceremonies. They decided to march specifically in honour of the memory of those women who were victims of war in that they were raped, and they started to plan this march.

As news of their intentions spread, some alarm was expressed by the spokespeople for the Returned Services League. Without any proper investigation of the issue, without any consultation with the locally elected representatives of the Australian Capital Territory-I include here representatives in the House of Assembly and the elected representatives in the House of Representatives and the Senate-the Minister for the Capital Territory decided to introduce hurriedly, overnight, and with no consultation, a new piece of legislation. It was a piece of legislation of the most serious character in that it placed a very serious restriction on civil liberties and introduced a new series of criminal offences. My colleague Senator Evans will make some comment this evening on that legislative action. When news of the Minister's action became known publicly in Canberra a very large number of women were very distressed and outraged by this action, which they felt was discriminatory, a gross over-reaction and, indeed, a grossly inappropriate reaction to the intentions of the women. So the group wishing to participate in the Anzac Day ceremony in the entirely appropriate way I have described grew larger.

On the morning of the march about 300 women assembled, not on Anzac Parade where the march is held but in a side street, Geerilong Gardens, which led on to Anzac Parade. The women assembled and discussed how they were to proceed in order to carry out their intention of participating in the march in a dignified and peaceful fashion. They were briefed by spokespeople for the group as to the method of marching, which was to be in silence and in two rows. After a short ceremony, during which they maintained a minute's silence and a poem was read, the women formed up behind banners. About 300 women were present. Some men had joined the gathering. They were asked not to join the march but rather just to express their support for it.

The women started to move forward to the street where the march was to be held but they were told by the spokespeople that if they felt that pushing forward would cause arrest they ought to fall back quietly and wait until matters settled down. There was never any intention to act in a confrontationist or disruptive way. The women moved on through Geerilong Gardens, and as soon as they entered Cooyong Street, which is still not the main street where the parade is held, they were prevented from moving forward by a police blockade extending across footpaths and roads with a backup force further down Cooyong Street. Bystanders have observed that about 70 police were blocking the way. The policeman read the ordinance and said that if the women attempted to move forward they would risk arrest. Organisers responded to this by asking the women to sit down and discuss a plan of campaign. During this time the women were quiet and their actions were restrained. Nothing happened to encourage the police to think that the women would be in any way offensive in their actions.

After the reading of the ordinance by the sergeant in charge, different alternatives were discussed. Finally, it was decided that the group would break up and that the women would attempt to proceed as individuals and re-form when they reached Anzac Parade, but again they were prevented from doing that. I say at this point that I believe the Australian Federal Police, the police who serve the electorate I represent, were put in an impossible position by the ordinance. For reasons that Senator Evans will spell out, the ordinance is very difficult for the police to interpret and there was a great deal of indecision on their part as to how they should proceed to maintain law and order when the law was, indeed, a very difficult one. They were required by the law not to prevent something that was actually happening but to prevent something which perhaps was intended to happen. Of course, the police had to be mind-readers in this matter.

My criticisms are not of the Federal Police, who were given a very difficult and, indeed, impossible task to do, but of the legislation and the three Ministers who put their names to this outrageous piece of subordinate legislation. When the time came for some of the women to decide to join the parade, of course there was a confrontation with the police and a number of them-I am told about 60-were arrested. However, not all of the women were arrested. Some of them were able to pass through. They re-formed at the head of the parade. When the rest of the march was over they marched quietly to the Remembrance Stone and placed their wreath. They were quiet and reverent during the whole episode. So where are we? As I said, there was no confrontation with marchers and no disruption of the march. The confrontation was with the police, who had been forced by the ordinance to prevent the women who were seeking to join the march from taking part. That confrontation took place in a side street and, as the record will support, did not disrupt the march. It certainly did not disrupt the ceremonies involving the laying of the wreaths.

I have gone through that account in some detail because the truth in this case is so very different from the wild impressions that were created by some of the media reports as to what happened. I am particularly critical of the national ABC report, which I saw, and the Channel 7 national report, which I also saw. Both of them used film clips showing the arrests and presented them to the viewer in such a way as to give the viewer the impression that the arrests were actually occurring in the body of the march. I discovered to my distress and horror that some of my own colleagues had formed this impression from watching the ABC and Channel 7 national news. I cannot say what other television news coverage presented such reports because I did not see any others. I think a proper examination of what took place will reveal the facts to be as I have presented them.

I wish to proceed now to the matter of the way in which Mr Hodgman has behaved. I wish to make it quite clear that my criticism is not of the Returned Services League. I disagree entirely with the view adopted by the RSL over this matter and I am very disappointed that a man such as Sir William Keys should have expressed the views that he expressed and that the local RSL organisation should have adopted the view that it adopted. But this is a democracy and if they have a view they are entitled to put it. They are entitled to put it to a Minister. They are entitled to ask a Minister to act in a certain way. My criticism fundamentally is not of them. They are entitled to have their view and to ask for what they asked for. But the Minister for the Capital Territory is not entitled to bring in an entirely repressive piece of legislation overnight with no consultation. He had no consultation with his Liberal Party colleagues in the Australian Capital Territory-with Elizabeth Grant of the House of Assembly or with Senator-elect Margaret Reid. Not only is he not entitled to do that but also he is to be criticised in the strongest possible terms for his garbled, untruthful version of the events and for the attempted justification of his own behaviour that he gave on AM yesterday morning. I have never heard such a concoction of untruths, distortions and exaggerations brought forward in what obviously amounted to an hysterical attempt to justify in retrospect his own outrageous and unjustifiable action. I shall draw attention to some of the more outrageous comments made by the Minister. Mr Hodgman said on AM yesterday:
The law was introduced for two reasons. Firstly, the existing law was felt not to be adequate-

Let me ask the Minister: By whom was it felt not to be adequate? The national capital has had marches, demonstrations, rallies and meetings of a vast variety of character, motive, organisational structure and so forth and yet the existing laws have been adequate to maintain law and order and the peaceful operation of these activities, so why was the law suddenly inadequate? If there was to be any improper attempt to disrupt a public event the existing laws clearly were adequate. That was the first outrageous untruth that the Minister delivered himself of over national radio. He continued:
but more importantly we received very detailed reports that a group was planning to disrupt the Anzac Day observance in the National Capital.
He said that the reports were frightening because they indicated that a number of extreme feminists, particularly from the Sydney area, would be coming to Canberra. He went on to say:
. . . representatives of both the Marxist and Lesbian groups within the Feminist Movement which is a front . . .
He said:
. . . in reality it was an attempt to sabotage the solemn remembrance of Anzac Day . . .
He said that he had information. He said that he could not respond personally to a particular question, but said:

Our information was, and has been confirmed independently by a phone call from, in fact, a member of the group, that they have met over the last three weekends planning this, that a number were planning to lie down in front of the soldiers and the ex-servicemen and women . . . the use of spray guns filled with paint . . .
The ABC reporter properly asked:
Where did the report come from?
Mr Hodgman replied:
The report is both an official police report and secondly information which was provided to us by a person who actually infiltrated the group . . .

I do not believe that claim by the Minister. I believe that it is an hysterical fabrication by somebody trying to cover his own tracks. I think it is the lowest form of political activity for a Minister to go on national radio and say: 'We did this outrageous thing, we introduced this outrageous legislation, because we were informed that certain outrageous things were going to take place'. Where is the evidence? If Mr Hodgman has been so informed, if he does have an official report, let him make that report public in the Parliament. If he does not, he is condemned permanently-I think he deserves it-as a person who tells outrageous untruths. I believe it is detrimental to the functioning of democracry and to the credibility of the Parliament for a Minister to use an an excuse for outrageous action that he had a secret informant, that he had seen a secret report, and to make such crazy assertions about the character of the women who participated.

It would not come as a surprise to honourable senators that I know many-probably most-of the women who participated in this action. I can assure honourable senators that the fantastic characterisation of the women as presented in Mr Hodgman's remarks could not be further from the truth. I know returned servicewomen who wished to join the march this year in that way. I know women who have been long-standing members of community organisations, parents and citizens organisations and conservative women's organisations who wished to join the march in this way. For Mr Hodgman to try to justify his own action by such grossly untruthful and insulting characterisation of these women is, I believe, a total debasement of parliamentary standards in this country.

The only other point I wish to make is about the constant harping by the Minister on the claim that the feminists wanted to disrupt the march for political purposes. I cannot understand what that means. What would be the political purpose? Is he suggesting that they are members of a political organisation which is opposed to Anzac Day? I know of no political party which expresses opposition to Anzac Day. Certainly my own political party has no opposition to Anzac Day. Indeed, representatives of the Labor Party participate and are honoured to participate in the observance of Anzac Day. Several times I have had the honour to represent the Leader of the Opposition in this matter and I have been honoured to do so. Where is the political party, where is the political cause, which is supposed to be hostile to the spirit of Anzac Day? There is no such political cause. I claim that Mr Hodgman, the Minister for the Capital Territory, was seeking to score a cheap political point, seeking to exploit the kind of prejudices that exist in the community about the women's movement, seeking to curry favour with a very strong and articulate lobby group, the RSL, and that in seeking to do all those rather contemptible things he has acted in a way which is detrimental not only to his own party and to the Government but also to the Parliament in general. I recognise that that matter will not end here, but that is what I have to say. I hope that those sections of the media which were so quick to misrepresent what actually occurred will pay some attention to my words tonight and make some attempt to set the record straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak upon the question of the Anzac Day observance in Canberra last weekend. I do not want, however, to canvass the events of that particular day and the merits of what may or may not have occurred both on the day and in the run-up to it. That matter has been covered admirably by Senator Ryan. There is no point in retreading the same path. I wish, however, to express my profound concern and, indeed, that of the Opposition at the terms of the law which was brought into operation for this purpose-the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981-and the circumstances of its promulgation, and to do so from the perspective of a party concerned-indeed, our opponents are equally concerned-with civil liberties and the rule of law.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw attention in particular, as briefly as I can, to a number of matters which I believe it is relevant for the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to take into account when it considers this question as I understand it will, on Thursday morning, and to express my hope that that Committee will recommend the disallowance of this particular Ordinance, bearing in mind that one of its obligations is to scrutinise delegated legislation to ensure 'that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties' because, as I hope will become clear, it is a very obvious indeed that this Ordinance offends that particular principle.

The amendment to the Traffic Ordinance was announced on Thursday last, 23 April, in a joint statement from three Ministers-the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, and the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman. It is accordingly no answer for the Attorney-General to shelter, as he endeavoured to do in Question Time today when this matter was raised, behind the frame of Mr Hodgman, as ample, as florid and as loud as that frame might be. The Attorney-General has lent the dignity of his office to this amendment and he stands equally responsible for the Ordinance with the other Ministers involved. I make that clear. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the terms of that statement.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
JOINT STATEMENT
By: The Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack, The Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Kevin Newman, and The Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Michael Hodgman.

The Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack, the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Kevin Newman, and the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Michael Hodgman, today annuonced amendments to the A.C.T. Traffic Ordinance which have the objective of preventing Anzac Day Parades in Canberra and Anzac Day observances at the Australian War Memorial being disrupted by protesters. The Ministers said the amendments were designed to ensure that next Saturday's Anzac Day Parade would be able to proceed in a peaceful and dignified manner.

The amendments, which were notified in the Gazette today, make it an offence for persons to disrupt an Anzac Day Parade or an observance or ceremony at or near the Australian War Memorial. In addition, a member of the Australian Federal Police of or above the rank of sergeant will be able to direct a person not to take part in the Anzac Day Parade where there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person is likely to disturb the parade. It will be an offence for a person to contravene such a direction.

The Ministers said the amendments were designed to preserve the dignity of Anzac Day. They added that this year's parade would again include a contingent of youth who had first participated in 1979, the International Year of the Child. This year approximately 500 young people from Canberra were expected to march.
23 April 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of the Ordinance itself, as I will spell out in a moment, were very far-reaching indeed. Perhaps for the moment they can best be left to speak for themselves. I seek leave to incorporate the text of that Ordinance in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY
Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981
An Ordinance to amend the Traffic Ordinance 1937
Short title
1. This Ordinance may be cited as the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981.
2. After section 23 of the Traffic Ordinance 1937 the following section is inserted:
Anzac Day parades
''23A. (1) Where-
(a) a person is taking part, or attempts to take part, in an Anzac Day parade; and
(b) there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person is likely to commit an offence against sub-section (3),
a member of the Australian Federal Police of or above the rank of Sergeant may direct the person not to take part in the parade.
''(2) A person who contravenes a direction given under sub-section (1) is guilty of an offence and punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding $100.
''(3) A person who-
(a) disturbs or disrupts-
(i) an Anzac Day parade; or
(ii) an observance or ceremony conducted at the building known as the Australian War Memorial on 25 April in any year;
(b) acts in a manner likely to disturb or disrupt such a parade, observance or ceremony; or
(c) engages in conduct offensive or insulting, or likely to give offence or cause insult, to persons taking part in such a parade, observance or ceremony,
is guilty of an offence punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding $100.

''(4) In this section, a reference to an Anzac Day parade shall be read as a reference to a parade of persons on 25 April in any year organized by The Returned Services League of Australia, and includes a reference to such a parade of persons assembled at or near the building known as the Australian War Memorial.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Ordinance was made, like all others for the Australian Capital Territory, by Executive decree, by the Governor-General, that is, acting on the advice of the Federal Executive Council. It was gazetted last Thursday and it was enforced last Saturday, merely two days later without any opportunity for its being considered by any legislative body and certainly not by the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly because, of course, that has no legislative powers at all with respect to ordinances or anything else and not by this Parliament which does, of course, have some powers with respect to ordinances of this kind, namely, the power to disallow them. The Ordinance was enforced in the circumstances which have just been outlined by Senator Ryan and which have been very elaborately retailed by the written media and by some television reports, in particular, that of Channel 10.

SPEECH.PARA: In those circumstances 64 people, mostly women, were arrested last Saturday for breaches of various provisions of the Ordinance, overwhelmingly, I understand, for breach of those provisions relating to a failure to obey a police direction given under the terms of the Ordinance. I do not want to say anything about the way in which those arrests were conducted. It may in fact be that the police, or at least some of them, did behave rather badly and certainly there is evidence of a failure by some or perhaps even all relevant police officers to wear appropriate identification marks, in particular, their police numbers. But that is a matter which can be left to another occasion to explore. It may be, on the other hand, as Senator Ryan has indicated in what she said that the police were in fact put in an intolerable position by the terms of this Ordinance and the way in which they acted was no more than the way in which they were required to act given the all embracing character of the conduct prohibited by the Ordinance in question. I simply want to focus on the terms of the Ordinance itself, not on the surrounding circumstances and to express quite succinctly three basic objections which I believe the Regulations and Ordinances Committee should consider very closely when it is dealing in the first instance with this matter.

The first objection to this Ordinance is the fact that it has been enforced by arrest, by charges and presumably it will follow, by fines before the legislature of this national Parliament has had an opportunity to consider it in any way through its normal processes of consideration with a view to possible disallowance. It is a classical exercise of criminal law making by the Executive and as such is at odds, I believe, with fundamental democratic principles. That, of course, is a fundamental flaw in our whole system of delegated legislation making and in particular has been a long running flaw so far as the Ordinances of the Australian Capital Territory are concerned which have all the character of fully fledged legislation in their own right rather than minor order, rules and regulations. This whole issue does raise the larger question of whether or not an appropriate legislative body, namely, the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, ought not to be exercising some proper legislative function with respect to laws of this kind. But there is even in the absence of any such domestic law-making process of a representative parliamentary kind within the Australian Capital Territory an opportunity for legislative input into the Ordinance making or approving process and that is, of course, via the disallowance procedures of this Parliament. I regard it as absolutely intolerable that this Ordinance was enforced in the way in which it was, in the far-reaching, criminal sanction way in which it was without there having been an opportunity for prior consideration by the legislature. I do not know of any precedent of this kind of action by way of enforcement of an Executive decree before there has been an opportunity for parliamentary consideration. There may have been one in respect of the notorious events in 1972 surrounding the removal of the Aboriginal embassy on which occasion I seem to recall reading about Senator Cavanagh's raising this very same question about an Executive decree in fact being enforced through criminal sanction before the Parliament itself had had an opportunity to consider the matter. Certainly, the Attorney-General when I asked him a question during Question Time today could not produce any precedents for Executive laws of this kind and character and gravity being enforced in this way. He said that he would investigate whether there had been any such precedents and I will await with some interest the products of that investigation. I do note, however, that he was not quick in Question Time today to respond to my invitation to justify in principle this practice which has eventuated in respect of this Ordinance of enforcing through police processes a severe set of criminal sanctions without there having previously been an opportunity for legislative consideration of those sanctions. That is the first objection.

The second objection is that the Ordinance is completely unnecessary on any view, given the vast array of existing public order legislative provisions which govern marches, assemblies and demonstrations of all kinds in the Australian Capital Territory. Senator Ryan indicated in broad terms the inadequacy of the grasp of Mr Hodgman, as the responsible Minister, of the existing law in this respect in his claim that there were no appropriate sanctions.

Let me fill in the record perhaps in just a little more detail by listing and seeking the incorporation in Hansard of the terms of a series of legislative provisions which do bear directly on the kinds of circumstances that, we are told, were understood to be threatened in the run-up to last Saturday's Anzac Day parade. So far as marches themselves are concerned, I refer to section 23 of the Australian Capital Territory Traffic Ordinance. So far as the question of offensive or insulting behavious is concerned, I refer to section 17 of the Australian Capital Territory Police Offences Ordinance. So far as unlawful assemblies are concerned involving violence or the apprehension of violence, I refer to sections 6 and 8 of the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971-73. So far as the question of obstruction of police in the execution of their lawful duty in these kinds of situation is concerned, I refer again to the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971-73, section 9. I refer also to section 73 of the Police Offences Ordinance of the Australian Capital Territory. I refer to section 25 of the Police Ordinance of the Australian Capital Territory. Finally, I refer to section 64 of the Australian Federal Police Act which indeed, I understand, was used to prosecute 14 women in the 1980 Anzac Day Women Against Rape protest which unquestionably did involve some degree of physical disruption. So we had a precedent in exactly the sort of circumstances that apparently were contemplated, whether justifiably or not, by the Minister. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard for convenient reference, the text of all those provisions to which I have just referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. May I make it clear that in referring to those provisions I say absolutely nothing about their merits, because undoubtedly a number of them are over-broad in their actual and potential operation and a number unquestionably ought to be the subject of some review. I refer to them only in order to note their existence in the context of the claims that have been made about there being a vacuum in the present law of public order in the Australian Capital Territory, and accordingly the necessity for specific further legislative provision to be made to deal with threatened breaches of the peace or disruptions of this kind. It is an absolutely unfounded claim, as even the most cursory scrutiny of the terms of those legislative provisions that I have outlined will demonstrate.

SPEECH.PARA: The third and final objection that must be made to the terms of this Ordinance is that it is manifestly over-broad and far too vague and far-reaching in its terms and potential application. Let me remind the Senate of those terms. There are only three provisions. The first two concern the police powers of direction. Sub-section (1) of section 23A provides:
Where-
(a) a person is taking part, or attempts to take part, in an Anzac Day parade; and
(b) there are reasonable grounds for believing that the person is likely to commit an offence against sub-section (3),
a member of the Australian Federal Police of or above the rank of Sergeant may direct the person not to take part in the parade.
That is followed by sub-section (2), which provides:
A person who contravenes a direction given under sub-section (1) is guilty of an offence and punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding $100.

So far so good. That is a simple and familiar power for police to give directions in situations in which they believe that there is reasonable ground to assume that an offence-later defined-will be committed. So far it is not especially offensive-it is quite a familiar provision-but this all assumes meaning and content when one gets to sub-section (3), which actually lists what the offences are. It provides:
(3) A person who-
(a) disturbs or disrupts-
(i) an Anzac Day parade; or
(ii) an observance or ceremony conducted at the building known as the Australian War Memorial on 25 April in any year--

I express no objection to the reference to disturbance or disruption because, clearly, the solemnity of the Anzac Day occasion is such that it ought not to be subject to disturbance or disruption, as those words are properly defined. Again, perhaps so far so good, except to the extent that there are other legislative provisions which would secure exactly the same end. Paragraph (b) goes on to put in the next component:
acts in a manner likely to disturb or disrupt such a parade, observance or ceremony;
That is a little more questionable because it is a little more vague, but nonetheless is probably acceptable in principle. The real problem starts with paragraph (c), which states:
(c) engages in conduct offensive or insulting, or likely to give offence or cause insult, to persons taking part in such a parade, observance or ceremony, is guilty--
This is the penalty provision which applies to all three of those situations-
of an offence punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding $100.

The first of these substantive offences is causing a disturbance or disruption. The second is acting in a manner likely to cause a disturbance or disruption-which is one removed from what the person is actually doing and depends on the response of the person who is reacting to the behaviour in question. For that reason it is a little more questionable.

The third is really quite an extraordinary provision in that it prohibits the person from engaging in conduct offensive or insulting, or likely to give offence or cause insult, to persons taking part in such a parade.

It should be fairly obvious that what we have here is a situation of subjective impression, subjective responsibility, which determines the application of criminal sanctions, applicability of arrest, the applicability of charges and the applicability of convictions and fines of up to $100. What we have is a situation which by itself is bad enough because it means that someone who is engaging in the kind of conduct which is likely to cause offence or insult to any person taking part in an Anzac Day parade-be he the most reactionary RSL person with the most far-reaching views as to the intolerability of any person wanting to register a different kind of solemn expression of commemoration on Anzac Day; anyone who offends subjectively the most extraordinarily susceptible person of that kind of view-is capable of bringing into force the operation of this provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does that differ from any of the offences in public places Acts or display of obscene literature Acts? They say 'if it is likely to cause offence to people'.

—I do not want to get into a long argument about this, but there are many offensive behaviour provisions in existing legislation which are cast in terms of a person who engages in behaviour which is offensive or insulting. The courts have tended to construe those sorts of provisions as meaning that the behaviour in question has to be of a character which not just subjectively causes an offended response from the person witnessing such behaviour but is reasonably likely to cause offence to a reasonably robust member of the community. In other words, there has to be some kind of objective test satisfied. Some court cases go further and establish, I think properly, a criterion of the likelihood of the behaviour in question actually causing a breach of the peace or causing a disturbance of some kind. I think it is appropriate that public order legislation, particularly when it is built around the causing of offence or insult have an objective component of that kind and one relating to questions of physical order. To the extent that the law does not clearly so provide then I think the law is deficient and ought to be subject to review.

SPEECH.PARA: I am making the point-it is a fairly obvious one really-that this legislation, on the face of it, is capable of operating to cause someone to be arrested and fined if he simply does something which, whatever its intrinsic dignity so far as one kind of spectator is concerned, is by its very character a form of action which is likely to cause indignation to some other participant in the parade. It was clear that the mere act of the women here in wishing to lay a wreath in remembrance of women raped in war was such as act. If it is an act capable of causing indignation or an offended response to some participant in the parade the full force of this provision applies. One can show how bizarre this all is by turning the application of the section on its head and pointing out that it is equally capable of referring to someone who is offended by, let us say, someone of left wing inclinations who is nonetheless an old Digger who participates in the parade and who listens to the jingoistic utterances of an extreme and florid character advanced by some spokesman for the RSL or other organisation speaking from the rostrum.

On the face of this legislation, it is broad enough to encompass reactions of that kind. I think that demonstrates simply just how bizarre and far-reaching, over-broad and vague that provision is. It becomes even more so-it becomes totally indefensible-when one reads that provision in conjunction with the preliminary provision in sub-sections (1) and (2) about the disobedience of a direction given by a police officer. In other words if a police officer believes it likely that a person will commit the offence of being likely to engage in conduct which is likely to cause offence or insult to some person participating in a parade, we could have a situation of a direction being given which, if disobeyed, will result in a charge. So we have three subjective discretions piled one on top of the other, three subjective tests about states of mind-the policeman's state of mind about what he believes the person is likely to do by way of conduct, which in turn relates to the state of mind which a third person is likely to have on witnessing the conduct of the second person.

This is all very well if we are talking about some utterly innocuous regulatory provision which does not have any kind of criminal sanction attached to it. But when we have a piece of legislation which is capable, as was amply demonstrated last Saturday, of being enforced by the full might and fury of the police it is intolerable and indefensible to have provisions of this breadth. I make it clear that I think some of the provisions, much as those relating to causing actual disruption or disturbance, looked at entirely in isolation are perfectly defensible. No one on this side of the chamber or anywhere else would imagine that it is inappropriate for the law to prevent physical disruptions or disturbances at Anzac Day parades. However, I make the point that those provisions are unnecessary because they exist elsewhere. What is intolerable about this legislation is the way in which it creates that further category of offence, creates the right, or indeed almost the obligation, of the police to give directions to persons not to engage in conduct which is likely to cause offence in that third way. That was the particular head of this Ordinance on which the overwhelming majority of the people were arrested.

The only other point I want to make is that I think it is obvious enough from what I have said that the Ordinance, on its very face, does offend the criterion of trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties which it is the obligation of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to apply. The offensiveness to that criterion becomes even more obvious when one looks at this Ordinance in the context of the provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and in particular Article 21, which refers to the right of peaceable assembly being recognised and not interfered with, which covenant, of course, Australia has now not only ratified but also given legislative force to a limited extent in the recently enacted Human Rights Commission Bill. The terms of that covenant are set out and discussed in a manner that is extremely relevant to the present circumstances in a very recently published article in the Legal Service Bulletin for April 1981 headed 'Assembly laws and the Civil Rights Covenant' by Robin Handley. Again I seek leave to incorporate the text of the article in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
ASSEMBLY LAWS & THE CIVIL RIGHTS COVENANT
by Robin Handley

Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on 13 August 1980; under Article 49, the Covenant came into force three months later, on 13 November 1980. Article 21 of the Covenant provides:

The right of peaceful assembly shall be recognised. No restrictions may be placed on the exercise of this right other than those imposed in conformity with the law and which are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, public order (ordre public), the protection of public health or morals or the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.

By Article 2 (1) Australia has undertaken 'to respect and to ensure to all individuals within its territory and subject to its jurisdiction the rights recognised in the present Covenant'. By Article 2 (3) Australia has undertaken 'to ensure that any person whose rights or freedoms as herein recognised are violated shall have an effective remedy'.

Australia lodged certain 'Reservations and Declarations' with its Instrument of Ratification; with respect to Article 2, attention was drawn to Australia's constitution as a federal commonwealth, and to the division of powers between States and Federal legislative, executive, and judicial authorities. The implementation of the provisions of the Covenant will be divided (and shared) between the Commonwealth and the States. However, the making of laws for the Australian Capital Territory falls within the Federal sphere of authority,1 and the Federal Government must therefore accept responsibility for the implementation of all the provisions of the Covenant in that Territory.
ASSEMBLY IN THE ACT

As in other Australian jurisdictions, there is in the ACT no right of peaceful assembly, statutory or common law, enforceable in the courts. Any right of peaceful assembly that does exist is residual only; that is, whatever is left after taking account of all the legal restrictions on assembly.

Apart from a wide range of statutory and common law offences which may be committed during an assembly in the ACT,2 there is one overriding restriction on assembly: if the assembly involves 'a procession or parade of any kind upon a public street' then the Motor Traffic Ordinance, s.23 makes it an offence to organize such a procession or parade without the written permission of the Minister.3 This is similar to the position in Queensland, where a permit from the District Superintendent of Traffic is required for any meeting or procession on any road,4 and Western Australia, where the prior permission of the Commissioner of Police is required 'for any procession, meeting or assembly in any street, thoroughfare or public place'.5
THE GOVERNMENT'S OBLIGATION

Given its obligations under the International Covenant discussed above the Federal Government should now initiate a reform of the law of assembly in the ACT, so that the right of assembly expressed in Article 21 is given legal recognition, and an effective remedy for violation of that right is provided in accordance with Article 2, para. 3.6 Until the Federal Government takes steps to initiate such reform, it is in no position to put pressure on State Governments to amend their law. Justice R. M. Hope, speaking at a seminar on the teaching of human rights in June 1980, expressed the view that only in NSW and South Australia did the law recognize the right of peaceful assembly expressed in the International Covenant.

Time is short. Article 40 requires that, within one year of the Covenant taking effect, Australia should submit a report on the measures adopted which give effect to the rights recognized by the Covenant, and on progress made in the enjoyment of those rights.
REFORM

The most pressing need in the ACT is for the repeal of s.23 of the Motor Traffic Ordinance, and for a review of applicable statutory and common law provisions.7 Before proposing a replacement for s.23, I should mention briefly the comparable NSW and South Australian statutes.

The Public Assemblies Act 1979, s.4 (NSW), which came into effect on 1 August 1979, requires the organizers of an intended assembly to give written notice to the Commissioner of Police of the date of the proposed assembly, the location or route, the purpose, and the expected number of participants. At least seven days notice must be given, unless application is made to the court for authorization. Where the required notice is given, the Commissioner may apply to the Supreme Court, under s.6, for an order prohibiting the assembly-but he must first invite and consider representations from the organizers of the assembly. The hearing will be before a single judge, usually of the Administrative Law Division of the Supreme Court, whose decision is final and not subject to appeal.

The Public Assemblies Act 1972 (SA) provides a similar notification system8-although, by s.4(4), only four days' notice is required. The Chief Secretary, the Commissioner of Police, and the local council may each lodge objections with the person who served notice, at least two days before the date of the proposed assembly; objections must also be published in a newspaper in the State, or in such a way that they come to the notice of those intending to participate in the assembly. Objections must specify the grounds upon which the proposed assembly would 'unduly prejudice any public interest': s.4(6). When an objection has been made, any intending participant may apply to a judge for a determination, and the judge may, under s.5(2):

(a) if he is not satisfied that proper ground for any objection made to the proposal exists, quash the objection and approve the proposal; or (b) may approve any other proposals submitted to him before, or at the hearing of, the application.

Section 23 of the Motor Traffic Ordinance (ACT) should be replaced by new provisions, similar to those contained in the Public Assemblies Act 1979 (NSW) requiring the organizers of a demonstration expected to take place on a public street, to give seven days written notice (specifying the proposed time, date, route and expected numbers) to the Commissioner of Police. Within two days of receipt of this notice, the Commissioner might serve notice of an objection on the Supreme Court, and in the following two days there would be a hearing, when the onus would be on the Commissioner to satisfy the Court that he has reasonable grounds to fear serious public disorder.9 The Court would have power to make an order prohibiting the proposed demonstration or imposing such conditions as the Court thinks fit. Provision would also be made for the organizers of a demonstration to apply to the Court to waive the seven day notification requirement.
THE POSITION IN THE UNITED KINGDOM

The law of assembly is presently under review in the UK-the Government published a Green Paper in April 1980, reviewing the Public Order Act 1936 and related legislation.10 The Public Order Act, s.3(1), empowers a chief officer of police who 'has reasonable grounds for apprehending that the procession may occasion serious public disorder' to 'give directions imposing upon the persons organizing or taking part in the procession such conditions as appear to him necessary for the preservation of public order, including conditions prescribing the route to be taken and prohibiting the procession from entering any public place specified in the directions'. Where he is of the opinion that such measures are inadequate, s.3(2) empowers him to apply to the local council for an order prohibiting the holding of all or any class of public procession in a particular area for a period not exceeding three months. The local council may make such an order with the Home Secretary's approval. (In London, the Commissioner of Police may make such an order subject only to the Home Secretary's approval.)

This review of the legislation, and that undertaken by the English Law Commission of associated common law offences,11 were prompted by the anti-National Front demonstration in Southall, London in April 1979-when Blair Peach, the New Zealand teacher, was killed12-and by earlier violent demonstrations in Lewisham, Birmingham and Leicester. Concern has been voiced over the preventive considerations incorporated in the Public Order Act 1936, s.3. For example, is the 'serious public disorder' test too stringent? Should the test be relaxed so that a chief officer of police can exercise his powers where the risk is merely that of 'disruption to the local community'? How are the rights of those who wish to march to be weighted against the rights of the members of the local community to go about their everyday business?13 Another question is whether a ban imposed under s. 3 (2) should be the subject of judicial review; judicial review is unlikely at present because the courts would be reluctant to interfere with the judgment of a chief officer of police where he is 'of the opinion' that s. 3 (1) measures would be inadequate in preventing serious public disorder.14 These and other questions raised by this review, are relevant to Australia, and the Federal Government should give them careful consideration before formulating its proposals for reform of the law of assembly in the ACT.
