TALK.START.PARA: —The importance of this article is that it not only demonstrates how the text of the Covenant is relevant to assembly laws generally but also that it focuses quite specifically on the present laws governing assembly in the Australian Capital Territory. I believe that as such it is a very useful reference document for honourable senators and, in particular, for members of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not underestimate the difficulty of drafting and enforcing public order legislation generally. I am really picking up some of the points I was endeavouring to make in answer to Senator Puplick. This is a notoriously sensitive and difficult area of the law where there is undoubtedly a legitimate community interest on the one hand in avoiding public disorder, both generally and certainly in specific situations of a solemn and dignified kind such as Anzac Day marches, but where equally clearly there is an interest not only of individuals but also of the community as a whole in preserving so far as is humanly possible the rights of free speech and expression of members of the community. Of course, the difficulty is in ensuring that those rights can be exercised in a way that will not create intolerable situations of disturbance and disorder. I believe that in this sort of conflict situation the law should bend over backwards not to penalise for its own sake behaviour which is potentially offensive to some classes of persons within the community. It is just too easy for too much behaviour to satisfy that description, whether it is inherently disruptive, remotely violent or physically disturbance-creating in its character. I believe that far too many of our offensive behaviour and public order laws are cast in over-broad terms, although there has been some attempt in the recent development of common law to limit the operation of those laws in the way I was endeavouring earlier to describe to Senator Puplick.

I do not want to labour any of these points now because I believe that the whole question of the appropriateness of this ordinance is, in the first instance, properly a matter for the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to deal with. I believe that the Committee should, as I have said, look very carefully at this Ordinance. It is difficult to believe that when it does, applying the criteria that it is obliged to, it will be able to do otherwise than recommend its disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep my colleagues more than a few minutes. I would like to comment mainly on what Senator Ryan said. Senator Evans ended his very flowery description of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) by saying: 'He is loud'. Having listened to half an hour of Senator Evans, I suggest that the honourable senator might be the pot calling the kettle black. Senator Ryan indulged in a very personal attack on the Minister for the Capital Territory. Obviously she does not know him very well. As a close colleague of his, I can assure her that he very thoroughly researches any statements he makes. Senator Ryan went to great lengths to tell the Senate that the women protesters at the Anzac Day parade in Canberra had no intention at any stage of confronting the marchers and that, indeed, they did not. Of course they did not because when they attempted to do that, the police stopped them. She assured us that originally it was to be a very peaceful protest by the women and that there would be no confrontation, that the organisers had gone to great lengths to tell everyone to be calm and peaceful. As a throw-away line she said, however, that 60-odd people were arrested by the police. It is hardly very peaceful when 64 women are arrested by the police. I hardly think it was the sort of thing that Senator Ryan was trying to tell us it was.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan did not say where the 300 women came from. I would be most interested to know the addresses of those who were arrested. The Minister indicated that many of the women had come from Sydney to join the march.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that to do with anything?

—Senator Melzer asks: 'What has that to do with it?' We have heard about these political demonstrations before. We talk of 'pay-a-demo'. There is no doubt that we have had another pay-a-demo in this attempted demonstration on Anzac Day in the Australian Capital Territory. It will be interesting to see where the women came from. I do not doubt that some of the women who Senator Ryan knows intended to be peaceful, but how often have we had demonstrations in this country when the organisers have said: 'but we had so many infiltrators from outside who disrupted it; we had no intention of it going this far'? It really does get out of hand. The Minister had information which I am quite sure that Senator Ryan would not have been privy to. But the Minister took steps to make sure that the disruption did not eventuate.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe Anzac Day is a very special occasion. Senator Tate may not consider it as special an occasion as I do, but I believe most Australians think Anzac Day has very special meanings for the majority of us. It is a day of reverence and of remembrance when every Australian who cares to do so can set aside some time just to say a simple thank you to those who gave their lives to preserve freedom, the right to demonstrate and the right to march. But we in this country must not allow demonstrations to interfere with that day. I back the Minister very much in that regard. The horrors of war, not only of Anzac Day itself but of every war that has occurred since Gallipoli, are understood. If the women were to look at those who have suffered in war and if they were at all legitimate they would have wanted to march on behalf of the children, who I believe are the greatest sufferers in any war. They are orphaned, abused and killed along with the soldiers and the women.

If every section of the community were to march in favour of its pet hobby-horse of the moment, a conglomeration of people on Anzac Day would try to tie their hobby-horse in with the horrors of war. We do not want Anzac Day desecrated in any way, and I am fully behind the Minister and the Ordinance. In Tasmania we saw an example of the types of women who tried to disrupt Anzac Day. They were exactly the same types of women and they did it for exactly the same purpose. They disrupted the Anzac Day march in Hobart and created a tremendous scene. They also were arrested, of course. The media picked them up instead of photographing the old soldiers and the young soldiers who were marching down the street outside the town hall. The full account of these women trying to barge into the middle of the march with their placards and their screaming and yelling was something I would not like to see again in Canberra or in any other city of Australia. The Minister has my full support. No doubt I will have an opportunity to debate the Ordinance if it should ever come on for disallowance in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to make a few things clear. I question whether in the debate tonight we are not trying to influence a jury as to the innocence or guilt of some women who find themselves in breach of the law. They were arrested and, I suppose, must face charges. It would be a sad day if the judge trying the case were influenced by the remarks of Senator Walters that they were poor types of women who came from Sydney and who deserved what they got because 60 of them were arrested.
—Or influenced to the contrary.

—Or influenced to the contrary. Fortunately those who know Senator Walters as well as we do know that she is not a reliable witness because of her prejudice against those who support freedom. I have been a member of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee for some considerable time, and I think the whole point of this question is that it is a sorry state of affairs that one man has the ability to make legislation. It is one of the things we have to face up to in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan said she did not think it right that the Minister could legislate in this way. But he is entitled to do so. The Parliament gives him that right. A conference of delegated legislation committees of Commonwealth Parliaments was held in Canberra last year. In a brilliant address Professor Reid pointed out that it is wrong to refer to subordinate legislation, which immediately suggests that there are two kinds of legislation in Australia. In fact, we have delegated legislation. There are not two kinds of legislation. The enactment of an ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory is as enforceable as any law the Parliament may make. We have given the Minister the power to make a law under which someone can be fined $100 without referral to the Parliament. As Professor Reid pointed out, Parliament has only one power under the Constitution, that is the power to make laws. We have given that power to someone else. The only power we have as a parliament is to make laws.

We recognise the necessity of delegated legislation because it is impossible for parliament to decide every matter. Therefore, we have established a regulations and ordinances committee to examine laws made in this way, report to Parliament and, if necessary, recommend their disallowance. But we have not altered the Acts Interpretation Act or the procedure by which a regulation is enforced so that it shall not apply until the Parliament approves it. An ordinance applies as soon as it is gazetted. One man decides whether it will be an offence to do anything in the Australian Capital Territory. When the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has submitted a report and one House disallows an ordinance it no longer applies. But between sessions of Parliament it can be law for three months. It could gaol half the people in Canberra in that period. Those are the things we have to face. We have to face up to the fact that ordinances should not become operative until the Senate has at least had an opportunity to review them. In England a regulation or ordinance has to receive an affirmative vote in the House of Commons before it passes into law. In Australia we give the Minister the right to make a law.

I am not one who upholds the sanctity of Anzac Day. Having studied the landing at Gallipoli, whilst I know of the sacrifice made, it has always been to me a commemoration of the mistake of a politician and a military leader. But I recognise that many people in Australia regard the day as sacred. On no account would I interfere with their right to respect that day. Senator Ryan said that there was no intention to disrupt the Anzac Day march. She knows most of the women involved. They did not tell her that they intended to cause a disruption. But we heard the contrary view of Senator Walters that there was an intention to disrupt because 60 women were arrested, some of whom came from Sydney. What a basis for an allegation! Senator Ryan knew that there was no intention. Yet a visitor to Canberra, speaking in support of her Minister, stated that the women are guilty before they go to court because there was once a confrontation in Hobart. Canberra women do not act in the same way as Hobart women act, as we have seen from the remarks of the honourable senator. We must therefore condemn the Minister for his action in this dispute. The arrest, as Senator Evans has pointed out, of anyone performing an action which would cause a disruption, and it being a breach to do anything which, apparently in the opinion of a constable, may create a breach, would not stand up to parliamentary scrutiny. I do not think that Parliament, as the law-making body of the Commonwealth would let such a law, which would infringe on human rights, go unchallenged.

Apparently 60 women have to face prosecution and may be convicted in accordance with a law which may not have the sanction of Parliament. It could be rejected when it comes before Parliament. It is a law which Parliament has no time for. It is an enforceable law because a Minister, out of touch with the feelings of Parliament, the elected representatives of the people, decided that he should do this. The decision is not right. There should be no enforcement of the law until such time as Parliament has had a look at it and either endorses it or gives a decision on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter, and I do so simply because a gratuitous insult was offered to me by Senator Walters in the course of her remarks. Out of the blue she stated, without any provocation on my part, that I had no reverence for or understanding of the significance of Anzac Day. In fact at five o'clock, early in the frosty, cold, north-west morning--
—Senator Tate!
—This is what the honourable senator said, and I am replying. I am exercising my right of reply, if the honourable senator will listen.
—Will you read Hansard tomorrow?

—I certainly will, and it will confirm what I say. I got up on Anzac morning at 5 a.m. and went to the dawn service, as is my practice, because whilst I do not attend the march I find the dawn service, with the playing of the bugle and the small band of ex-servicemen remembering their dead comrades, a very moving and significant event. I wish to place on record that I understand and reverence the significance of Anzac Day insofar as it is a remembrance of the dead.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to comment either on the actual incident which is alleged to have taken place here in Canberra, or on whether the Ordinance is compatible with the ordinary civil liberties of persons in the Australian Capital Territory. Once again I place on record that it was due to my initiative and insistence that the legal counsel to the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee is providing as expeditiously as possible, by the Thursday morning meeting time, his legal opinion on whether in fact in his view the Ordinance transgresses the criteria set out by the Committee as guidelines to whether it should recommend to this chamber the disallowance of such an ordinance. It will be for that Committee and then for this chamber to make its judgment.

I think it would be much better if this matter were discussed in a calm atmosphere-whether it be in the committees of the Senate or in this chamber-rather than in the manner in which Senator Walters has put forward her case. During the course of her remarks she said that some of the women of the same type were arrested in Hobart. If I may say so, she in fact gave support to Senator Evans's case that there was an adequate array of laws available to deal with a disturbance or with a breach of the peace if in fact it occurred. On that score alone, this Ordinance was possibly unnecessary. But further, and more importantly, I think Senator Walters should recognise that in the 1950s an Australian government, in the cold war atmosphere, tried to bring forward an Act which was to be called the Communist Party Dissolution Act, in order to do the very same thing which Senator Walters wants to do, namely, condemn people because they can be recognised as belonging to a type. Not only did the High Court of Australia reject that approach as being beyond the Australian Constitution and the rule of law derived from Britain on which it is based, but also the Australian people, by referendum, rejected that approach. I commend that thought to Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had five speakers on this matter that arose on Anzac Day of this year. I think what has been said by Senator Tate ought to be taken into account by all of us at this time-a discussion is to be held by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I assume from the interest in this matter that it is highly likely that there will be a Senate debate on the Ordinance. Senator Cavanagh drew our attention to the difficulties that are experienced through delegated legislation. He reminded us of the activities of that Committee of the Senate which over a number of years and during his membership of it has brought to our attention from time to time matters which are subjected to disallowance by this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I comment on what Senator Ryan brought before us only to the degree that I heard a broadcast on the Australian Broadcasting Commission yesterday. I think her comment with regard to media misrepresentation is one that again would relate to her knowledge of the situation and perhaps not be able to be accepted without further information by others who had only the information that came from the media. It was interesting that Senator Walters also brought forward the same thought-a highlight was given to this aspect on Anzac Day this year not only in the Australian Capital Territory but also in her State of Tasmania. It seems that incidents of this kind can be given prominence over and above what is the objective of the march, the observance or the particular matter that perhaps ought to have wider attention.

Senator Evans brought forward to us a number of objections that he had to the Ordinance and even with regard to the incident. Again, I would not want to make a comment on those who have been subjected to arrest and who are to be dealt with before a court. I do not think it is encumbent on this place to transgress in any way what ought to be the proper discussion of these matters through the court. The precedents that were sought by Senator Evans from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) today at Question Time on the issue of enforcement before consideration by Parliament I am sure are in the hands of the Attorney-General. He said that he would investigate this. I am sure that if further information is to be brought forward that will be done in time for consideration by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

Senator Evans also listed a vast array of public order legislation which could be applicable. He incorporated a number of excerpts from Acts that he referred to. They will have the consideration of those who are interested in this matter. He also stressed his concern about the vagueness of the Ordinance and the fact that there may be some trespass on the civil liberties of people. Again I think that that is a matter that will be well covered by the consideration of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. The interest in the subject has raised the whole question of the women who are victims of rape in war. I believe that there are many aspects of war that need to be recalled and remembered on occasions. I heard a comment from the leader of the Returned Services League on this matter. He also said that he believed that all Australians found the question of rape totally abhorrent, whether it is in war or in other circumstances. Perhaps if we are to consider what was the objective of the people who did assemble on this occasion, we would need to consider that question as being an important one, at the same time understanding that Anzac Day in this country is a day of commemoration and is observed with a serious attitude by many thousands of people throughout the country.

I can only say that I am sure that all the speeches that have been made on this subject will be considered by those who have direct responsibility relating to the matter. I will ensure that the comments which have been made are brought to the attention of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and the Attorney-General. I feel sure that the Senate will have an opportunity for further consideration of this matter, if not in the Senate as a whole, certainly as is scheduled for the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. With those comments, I think that we should await now the outcome of that consideration to see whether further action is contemplated by the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role has the Department played in the development and operation of the UNEP International Referral System (INFOTERRA).
(2) What Australian sources contribute to the international system and what are the details.
(3) What governments currently participate in INFOTERRA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The International Referral System (INFOTERRA) of the United Nations Environment Program began operations in 1975 to facilitate international co-operation in environmental information exchange. It is a system through which organisations and individuals requiring environmental information can obtain the names and addresses of appropriate sources.

The Department of Home Affairs and Environment (and antecedent Commonwealth departments with responsibility for the environment) have been active in the development of INFOTERRA and in operating the Australian National Focal Point. The work of the Australian National Focal Point has included the following:
developing the Australian computer system during 1975 and 1976;

hosting, in 1976, an INFOTERRA Regional Workshop which was attended by representatives from Australian State Government authorities and from New Zealand, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and Papua New Guinea;
incorporating into the system Australian experts as sources of environmental information;
providing publicity about INFOTERRA to potential users and sources;
providing information in response to referral requests;
monitoring and evaluating the practical effectiveness of the system; and
exchanging development information with INFOTERRA headquarters and other National Focal Points.

(2) Over 500 Australian sources are registered in the INFOTERRA System. Most are from State Government authorities, tertiary education institutions and major research organisations (particularly CSIRO).

(3) As at September 1980, 111 countries have designated National Focal Points. Seventy two of these countries, together with 13 United Nations agencies, have contributed over 8,200 registered sources, covering a wide range of environmental information.
The participating countries include the United States, Canada, the United Kingdom, most other EEC countries, Japan, Russia, China and other countries in all regions of the world.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What procedures are available in Alice Springs for transfer of supporting parent's benefit to a grandparent where the grandparent has care of grandchildren.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Supporting parent's benefit is not transferable from one person to another. In order to qualify for supporting parent's benefit a sole parent must have the custody, care and control of a child of whom he or she is the natural parent, or must be a person living apart from his or her spouse or defacto spouse, in which case the child must have been in the person's custody, care and control at the time sole parenthood occurred.

A grandparent who assumes the custody, care and control of a grandchild would not normally meet the eligibility criteria for supporting parent's benefit. However, he or she may be eligible for some other form of financial assistance.

Where the grandparent is already in receipt of a social security pension or benefit, an additional payment of up to $10 a week may be made in respect of each child in his or her custody, care and control. If the grandparent is a single, widowed or divorced pensioner, a guardian's allowance of up to $6 a week may also be payable (up to $8 a week if the child is under six or an invalid). In these situations the maximum rate of pension is the same as for a supporting parent's benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Do the latest World Bank figures indicate that 800 million of the world's population are absolutely poor, and that non-government agencies are generally recognised as being able to reach the poorest of the poor more effectively than governments at grassroots level; if so will the Minister: (a) consider channelling a greater percentage of Australia's foreign aid budget through these agencies; and (b) consider raising the proportion of foreign aid channelled in this way from the present inadequate one-half of one per cent to four per cent, in line with the practice of most other developed countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The World Bank's 'World Development Report, 1980' states that there are 800 million people living in absolute poverty. Whilst the Report does not compare the effectiveness of the programs of governmental and non-governmental agencies it does recognise that non-governmental organisations (NGOs) can play an important role.
The Government also recognises the valuable contribution which NGOs can make to the alleviation of world poverty and in recent years has greatly increased its support for Australian NGOs.

In 1980-81 the Government's program of assistance to NGOs received a 32.5 per cent increase to $2.969 million. In addition the Government decided in September 1980 to grant tax deductibility for donations to 22 of Australia's major NGOs. This concession is a substantial extra Government contribution to the work of NGOs.

I acknowledge that NGOs have a capacity to disburse increased funds and that generally speaking their programs do assist the poorer groups in developing countries. However, the percentage of the foreign aid budget disbursed through NGOs depends very much upon the total aid budget and the competing priorities within the aid program. In 1978 my predecessor Mr Peacock indicated to the Australian Council for Overseas Aid that 1 per cent of Official Development Assistance (ODA) disbursed through NGOs was a useful benchmark at which to aim. I support this view and agree that the disbursement, which is currently at 0.54 per cent of ODA, should move towards this 1 per cent figure as budgetary circumstances permit.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March 1981 (Hansard, page 566) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the Australian Government provide food aid to Ethiopia? If so, how is it distributed when it arrives there? Can the Minister assure the Parliament that this aid is reaching the genuinely needy Ethiopian people rather than helping to feed Ethiopian and foreign troops fighting the Eritreans, as is happening with food aid from the European Economic Community.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
In 1979-80 Australia gave 6000 tonnes of wheat to Ethiopia and in 1980-81 Australia will give:
(i) 10,000 tonnes of wheat from Australia's bilateral contribution to the International Emergency Food Reserve (IEFR) through the World Food Program (WFP);
(ii) 5,000 tonnes of wheat from Australia's multilateral contribution to the IEFR through WFP;
(iii) 2,200 tonnes of wheat from Australia's bilateral Food Aid Convention contribution through WFP to replace maize given by Ethiopia to Uganda;
(iv) 10,000 tonnes of wheat from Australia's bilateral Food Aid Convention allocation to the Ethiopian Government. Total 27,200 tonnes.

Consignments (i)-(iii) will be distributed by the World Food Program for emergency feeding of drought and war-affected persons throughout Ethiopia. WFP also provides food aid in support of government programs to improve agricultural productivity. Consignment (iv) will be consigned to the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) which will exchange it for equivalent quantities of maize and distribute it in the regions of Wello, Eritrea, Tigrai, Haraghe, Bale Sidamo and Gamma Goffa to alleviate the shortage of food in drought-affected areas. As a condition of acceptance of the wheat the Ethiopian Government undertakes to provide a full accounting of the gift detailing regions, groups and numbers of recipients.

The Australian Development Assistance Bureau has endeavoured to establish that Australian aid is helping the genuinely needy Ethiopian people. The High Commission in Nairobi regularly sends officers to Ethiopia to report on the situation there.

In the most recent contact, the World Food Program (WFP) representative in Addis Ababa said that the primary responsibility for establishing who would receive the food aid in Ethiopia lay with the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) which worked in close conjunction with international relief agencies, voluntary agencies and bilateral donors. In the case of the WFP, it was normal practice for the RRC, in consultation with WFP to nominate intended recipients of assistance and for RRC proposal to be referred to WFP headquarters for authorisation prior to distribution. The actual physical task of distribution was undertaken under the auspices of RRC and they exercised firm control over the process.

The WFP had encountered only minor difficulties with the Ethiopians over their handling of food aid principally in relation to the lack of transport available for distribution. The Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission was scrupulous about keeping proper account of even the smallest amount of food aid. The RRC was quite prepared to have donors peruse their books.

WFP was asked about allegations that some food aid had been diverted to the Ethiopian Army or to Soviet or Cuban forces. WFP was not aware of any such instances. However, it was added that the allegations were probably based on a misunderstanding of wheat-maize exchange procedures. As wheat was a grain used by city dwellers rather than those in rural areas, donors including WFP, authorised the exchange of wheat received from donors for equal quantities of maize. The wheat was then freely available on the market. As the required exchange had already taken place the WFP did not follow through to investigate who the final purchasers might be but it was indeed possible that on occasions this could be the Ethiopian Army.

WFP also mentioned that to defray some of their costs WFP and probably other international agencies, sold empty bags, oil tins etc to market merchants. It did not cross out the WFP label as this would be a costly process and would negate the funds gained on sale of these items. However, it was possible that in the course of their use, some of these marked tins might find their way into use by the Army, which would lead to the conclusion that food aid had been deliberately diverted to the Army. During a recent trip to Eritrea, a High Commission officer saw a numer of 'EEC aid' butter oil containers being sold in the Asmara markets. The Army in the region frequently purchases supplies from market merchants and it is quite likely, given the shortage of containers of any variety, that EEC marked bags and tins would have found their way into military establishments and be the source of reports that European Economic Community aid is being used to feed Ethiopian and foreign troops.
